editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: TO THE HONORABLE SOCIETY OF THE MIDLE TEMPLE, ALL HEALTH AND PROSPERITIE.
div.p:
WHen it came neere my turne to reade, and that I had entred into the choice of my Statute, euen then my body (wa≈øted with long ≈øicknes and di≈øea≈øe) called vpon me to con≈øider rather of my death; and that ≈øo withdrew my minde from the po≈øitiue Lawe I had in hand, as that it ≈øetled my thoughts vpon that eternall law of God, wherby Statutum e≈øt h ‚Ä¢ minibus &c. It is appoynted vnto men that they ≈øhall once dye, and afterward come to iudgement; and when I had ≈øpent ≈øome time thereon, it did not only di≈ø≈øwade me from mine intended enterpri≈øe to reade, and per≈øwade me to giue way to a more fit Reader, but gaue me al≈øo ≈øuch comfort and content, as that thereout, I ≈øtraight way affected to impart it vnto you, to whom I ≈øhall euer wi≈øh as your Fo≈øter-brother, all ≈øatisfaction in the things of be≈øt v≈øe, toward
your pro≈øperitie in this life, and glorious e≈øtate in the life to come; excu≈øe I pray you the forme it coÃÑ meth to you in, as i≈ø≈øuing from a minde affected at that in≈øtant, with the order of a Temple reading, and therefore could receiue no other impre≈ø≈øion then of the ≈øame kinde; which neuerthele≈ø≈øe as it is, I doe not pre≈øume to addre≈ø≈øe vnto you for your in≈øtruction, but for your incoragement and incitation, that you (knowing me to be heauie and ≈ølow by nature, and little bettered by any art, and yet to haue by con≈øtant and diligent hearing of godly ≈øermons, and that only at our appoynted houres, and by addition of ≈øome things (≈øorting with the matter) collected out of my readings, gathered ≈øuch ≈øtore of Diuine notes, as that thereout, I may pre≈øent you with ≈øuch a common place as this) might from thence con≈øider, what excellent things may be compa≈ø≈øed by you, who as well for your naturall endowments, as your liberall bringing vp, doe farre exceede not only my ≈øelfe, but many other every way afore me; and this al≈øo you may performe without the lea≈øt preiudice to your pre≈øcribed ≈øtudies; for if your indeauours this way be but accompanied with delight, the one will be a recreation, yea, a very apt helpe to the other; For what maxime of the Common Law of this kingdom can you cite, whereby our infinite, and tho≈øe mo≈øt variable poynts and que≈øtions are decided, that is not grounded, or originally deriued from the eternall law of God, either by direct precept, or by con≈øequent implication: What I haue done in this my poore and ≈øimple labours is a part of my negotiation with that
one Talent I haue receaued from the Lord, which I am de≈øirous to put to the vttermo≈øt profite. And although perhaps for my ≈øelfe to be ≈øeene in the pre≈ø≈øe in a matter of this kinde, will be to ≈øome as great a wonder as Saul among the Prophets, yet had I rather by doing of ≈øome good this way, lay open my infirmities to the cen≈øure of men, then with the idle ≈øeruant to hide my Talent in the earth; Accept therfore I pray you this my pre≈øent, with that kinde affection I doe intend it, and then I hope it ≈øhall either profit you in the reading, as it hath done me in the compiling, or at lea≈øt, ≈øtirr you vp to correct and amend it by your owne endeauours, for your better v≈øe and comfort: And ≈øo wi≈øhing to you as to my ≈øelfe, I re≈øt euer at your ≈øeruice,

div.p: THE Statute which I haue cho≈øen to reade vpon, wanteth neither time to ≈øettle, authoritie to bind, nor notice to auoid excu≈øe. For in time it precedeth all time; for it was, and is from all eternitie; in authoritie of the Law-maker it exceedeth all that euer were, for all the three E≈øtates in that Parliament, were, now are, and euer ≈øhall be infinite in power, glory, wi≈ødome, fore≈øight, mercie and Iu≈øtice, and hath beene proclaimed to the World by many meanes; fir≈øt in Paradi≈øe, then by the Prophets, and la≈øtly by this holy Author to the Hebrewes, where it is thus written, Heb 9.27.

q.p: It is appointed vnto men that they ≈øhall once die, and afterward commeth the Iudgement.

div.p:
MY reading vpon this Statute, may for the better apprehen≈øion of the Law-makers meaning, be aptly put into the≈øe eight Diui≈øions following. viz.
1 The certaintie of death.
2 The meditation on death.
3 The preparation for death.
4 The right behauiour in death.
5 The comfort at our owne death.
6 The comfort again≈øt death of friends.

8 The glorious e≈øtate of the children of God after death.

div.head: THE FIRST DIVISION, OF THE certaintie of Death.
div.p: THis fir≈øt Diui≈øion containing the certaintie of death, is properly ≈øubdiuided into three parts: The fir≈øt is into the death (which is naturall) of the bodie: the ≈øecond is the ≈øpirituall death of the ≈øoule in ≈øinne: and the third is the eternall death of both body and ≈øoule in hell.
To the≈øe three deaths are oppo≈øed three liues, the life of Nature, of Grace, and of Glorie.

Naturall or bodily death, which is called the fir≈øt, (becau≈øe in re≈øpect of time, it goeth before the third in our vnder≈øtanding) is a di≈ø≈øolution or ≈øeparation of the ≈øoule from the bodie for a time, namely vntill the re≈øurrection.

The ≈øpirituall death which is termed the ≈øecond, is a perpetuall ≈øeparation of the ≈øoule principally, but con≈øequently of body and ≈øoule from God; of which, Sinne is the mother, the Diuell is the father, and Damnation is the daughter; and this is when men die not to ≈øinne, but in ≈øinne.
Eternall death is the hire and wages of the ≈øecond, and this euer followes the reprobate after the fir≈øt.

Both the≈øe latter are a ≈øeparation of the whole man, bodie and ≈øoule from the fellow≈øhip of God: The fir≈øt is an entrance to death, the ≈øecond and third are the accompli≈øhment of it. The fir≈øt is temporarie, the ≈øecond and third are ≈øpirituall and eternall. The fir≈øt is of the body onely, the ≈øecond and third are of both bodie and ≈øoule. The fir≈øt is common to all men, the ≈øecond and third are proper only to the Reprobates. But touching the naturall and bodily death, which is the proper
≈øubiect of this Diui≈øion, it is (as we haue ≈øaid before) the ≈øeperation of the ≈øoule from the bodie, with the di≈ø≈øolution of the bodie vntill the re≈øurrection, as a puni≈øhment ordained of God, and impo≈øed on man for ≈øinne, though to the godly the nature of it is chaunged. For when God had ≈øetled Adam in Paradi≈øe, a place of plea≈øure, giuing him ≈øuch libertie, as the≈øe words import, Thou ≈øhalt eate freely of euery tree of the garden; Gen. 2.16.17. yet left hee ≈øhould pre≈øumptuou≈øly equall him≈øelfe with his Creator, he gaue him this bridle to champe on, But of the tree of knowledge of good and euill thou ≈øhalt not eat, for in that day thou eate≈øt thereof, thou ≈øhalt die the death. Adam had ≈øoone forgotten this ≈øaying (thou ≈øhalt die) and harkened vnto that lying ≈øpeech of the Serpent, Yee ≈øhall not die. Matth. 15.14. The man gaue eare to the woman, the woman to the Serpent, they eate of the forbidden tree; ≈øo the blind led the blind, and both fell into the ditch. But now when Father Adam hath ta≈øted of that forbidden fruite, O, how was he bewitched? He was once in the ≈øtate of grace, but now of di≈øgrace, hee was once the childe of God, but now in danger (for ought he knoweth) to be the ≈ølaue of the Serpent. God did once care altogether for him, but now hee mu≈øt care and ≈øhift for him≈øelfe: hee was warme without apparell, naked without ≈øhame, ≈øatisfied without labour or paine, his meat was put into his mouth. But now it is come out of his no≈øtrels, and is loath≈øome vnto him. Numb. 11.20. And now hee mu≈øt be pinched with cold, and ≈øcorched with heate, Gen. 31.40. he mu≈øt trauell hard, and in the ≈øweat of his browes mu≈øt eate his bread. Gen. 3.19. While hee kept him≈øelfe within his compa≈ø≈øe hee was a happie man (for which he was to thank God) and now being in mi≈øerie, hee is accur≈øed and vnhappie, for which hee may thanke him≈øelfe. A lamentable fall, a pitifull ca≈øe, the wrath of God ouerrunneth the whole world, as a gangrene through all Adams po≈øteritie, for his di≈øobedience: his trea≈øon hath attainted all his children, his whole bloud is corrupted, his fall redoundeth to all of vs that came of him. Alas, then how ≈øhall we doe? Adam is du≈øt, hated of God, and a≈øhamed of him≈øelfe, he is accur≈øed, hee is ≈øicke with ≈øinne, hee is dead,
twice dead, ≈øubiect to mortalitie, and ≈øubiect to eternall damnation; his children bee in the ≈øame ca≈øe. Woe therefore bee vnto vs, we are ≈øo benumbed with our ≈øinnes, that wee feele not the ≈øting of death fixed therein, the impo≈øtume of ≈øinne lieth hidden in our hearts, ≈øo plea≈øingly to our carnall ≈øence, as that we thinke our ≈øelues whole and ≈øound, as if we pre≈øumed we ≈øhould neuer die. The incredulous and rebellious broode of Adam, will not acknowledge their corruption and mortalitie, ≈øuch and ≈øo great is their ≈øelfe-loue and pride of heart.

Adam the Father of all Nations was once a free-man, a ble≈ø≈øed man, the childe of God; the mercie of God imbraced him on euery ≈øide. In the earth there were ble≈ø≈øings for him ingrauen, as it were, in the herbes, flowers and fruits; yea in the heauens and in the waters, he ≈øaw innumerable tokens of Gods loue towards him: But alas, wretch that he was, when he was in honor he forgot him≈øelf, he denied God his ≈øeruice, yea he obeyed his Enemie; and therefore became accur≈øed, and debarred of all his former ble≈ø≈øings. He became a bondman, a cur≈øed creature, the ≈øeruant of ≈øinne and Satan, a≈øhamed of his nakedne≈ø≈øe, and trembled at Gods voice. So that death and the graue haue obtained the victorie; for Adam and his wife are become a cur≈øed couple; yea, not onely they, but all their po≈øteritie; they be the roote, we be the branches. If the roote bee bitter, the branches mu≈øt bee ≈øo al≈øo: they bee the Fountaine, we be ≈øprings; if the fountaine be filthie, ≈øo mu≈øt the ≈øprings be. Sinne and corruption bee the riches that wee bequeath to our children; Rebellion is the inheritance that we haue purcha≈øed for them: Death is the wages that we haue procured vnto them; ≈øuch as the father is‚ñ™ ≈øuch bee the children. For wee are all of the ≈øame nature, and haue eaten the ≈øame ≈øowre grape. Ezec. 18.2. The fathers haue eaten ≈øowre grapes and the childrens teeth are ≈øet on edge. By one man ≈øinne entred into the world, Rom. 5.12. and death by ≈øinne, and ≈øo death went ouer all men, in whom all men haue ≈øinned. In ≈øinning with Adam, wee mu≈øt all die with Adam; and this is the onely difference betwixt him and vs, that hee did it before vs, and for vs. For if any of vs had
beene in Adams ≈øtead, we had done that which Adam did, if not more, to procure death. And wee receiuing from Adam the infection of our fle≈øh, we receiued from him al≈øo the corruption of our fle≈øh. And this is the cheife≈øt and mo≈øt principall cau≈øe why all mu≈øt die. As the goodne≈ø≈øe of God hath lent vs life, ≈øo our owne de≈øerts haue wrought our death.

It is a true, and a heauie ≈øentence ≈øpoken to euery man, Thou mu≈øt die: verified not in one, in few, in many, but in all; and vniuer≈øall is this ≈øaying in re≈øpect of the elementarie creatures, All mu≈øt die. A ≈øhort clau≈øe of a long extent, containing in it the e≈øtate of all mortall creatures what≈øoeuer. As there are certaine common principles which doe runne through all Arts, ≈øo this is a generall rule that concernes euery man, All mu≈øt die. The truth thereof is daily to be ≈øeene, and all of vs hereafter ≈øhall proue (the Lord knoweth how ≈øoone) by his owne experience.

Therefore it is ≈øaid in the ≈øecond booke of E≈ødras. E≈ød. 2. v. 3.4.5.6.7. O Lord who beare≈øt rule, thou ≈øpake≈øt at the beginning when thou didde≈øt plant the earth (and that thy ≈øelfe alone) and commanded≈øt the people, and gaue≈øt a bodie vnto Adam without ≈øoule, which was the workman≈øhip of thine hands, and didde≈øt breath into him the breath of life, and he was made liuing before thee, and thou ledde≈øt him into Paradi≈øe, which thy right hand had planted, before the earth came forward, and vnto him thou gaue≈øt commandement to loue thy way; which he tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed, and immediately thou appointed≈øt death to him and his generation; of whom came Nations, Tribes, and Kindreds out of number. And in another place of that book it is ≈øaid, And when Adam tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed my Statutes, E≈ød. 2. v. 7.11.12. then was decreed that now is done. Then were the entrances of this world made narrow, full of ≈øorrow and trauell, they are but few and euill, full of perils and very painfull. But as a man cannot ≈øo well iudge of a ≈øumme, when it lies in the heape, as when it is tolde and numbred out: ≈øo if this vnited and contracted pre≈øentation of mi≈øeries, bee not ≈øo palpable enough in your conceits, behold to your full ≈øatisfaction I come to particulars. The whole denominates the parts. And doubtle≈ø≈øe when wee come to this
preci≈øe d ‚Ä¢ ≈øtribution, and narrow ≈øcrutinie, to the ≈øingling out of mi≈øeries and mortalitie, you will ble≈ø≈øe your ≈øelues that there are ≈øo few Bedlam-hou≈øes, and yet ≈øo many out of their wits, that cannot perceiue and di≈øcerne the ≈øame. And therefore let vs rippe vp the whole condition and ≈øtate of mankinde; and then you ≈øhall perceiue the frailties and mi≈øeries thereof, ≈øince the fall of our fir≈øt Parents. And this principally con≈øi≈øteth vpon the words of the holy man Iob, in the beginning of his fourteenth Chapter, Iob 14.1.2: where he ≈øaith, Man that is borne of a woman, is of ≈øhort continuance, and full of mi≈øeries. Hee ≈øhooteth forth as a flower, and is cut downe, he vani≈øheth al≈øo as a ≈øhadow, and continueth not. To the end we might want nothing in the de≈øcription of humane calamities, it ≈øeemeth his purpo≈øe and drift was to begin with the very matter it ≈øelfe, of the which man was made. For he is called Homo ab humo, becau≈øe he was made and created of the earth; neither was he made of the be≈øt of the earth, but of the ≈ølime (as the Scripture doth te≈øtifie) being the mo≈øt filthie and abiect part of the earth; among≈øt all bodies the mo≈øt vile element, among≈øt all elements the earth is the ba≈øe≈øt, among≈øt all parts of the earth, none is more filthy and abiect then the ≈ølime.

Wherefore man was made of that matter, then the which nothing is more vile and ba≈øe. And whereas he ≈øaith that hee was borne of woman, he hath in few words comprehended many mi≈øeries of humane condition. For fir≈øt of all our verie fa≈øhioning and breeding in the wombe, is ≈øo vnpure and vncleane, that it is not for cha≈øt eares to heare, but to be pa≈ø≈øed ouer in ≈øilence.

Furthermore, after that man is once conceiued, doth he not endure great calamities in his mothers wombe, as it were in a filthie and vncleane pri≈øon, where euery moment he is in perill of his life? At the la≈øt he is borne naked, weake, ignorant, de≈øtitute of all helpe and coun≈øell, not able to goe, to ≈øpeake, nor to helpe him≈øelfe; and all that he can doe, is to crie, and that is to ≈øet forth his mi≈øeries. For he is borne to labour, a bani≈øhed man from his countrie, in po≈ø≈øibilitie to liue a few daies and
tho≈øe full of mi≈øerie and perill, deuoid of all quietne≈ø≈øe and re≈øt.
Behold then the very beginning from whence man hath his fir≈øt originall and breeding.

In the next place the ≈øhort time comes to be con≈øidered, and for that Iob ≈øaith further, that man is of ≈øhort continuance, and herein you may behold ≈øome other calamities of mans bodie, the building being ≈øcarce fini≈øhed is readie to totter, and ≈øure ere long to fall. Man is ≈øcarce entred into the world, when as he was admoni≈øhed to remember his departure out of the ≈øame againe. Man (≈øaith holy Iob) being borne of a woman, is of ≈øhort continuance, and full of mi≈øeries. Euery word hath a great empha≈øis, He is full of mi≈øeries euen from the ≈øole of the foote to the crowne of the head, there is no ≈øoundne≈ø≈øe in it, E≈øay 1.6. but wounds and brui≈øes, and putrifying ≈øores. Not only the body, but the mind al≈øo, ≈øo long as it is captiued in the pri≈øon of the body; Thus no place is left emptie and free from mi≈øeries. Mans mi≈øeries are many and great, there is no member, no ≈øence, no one facultie in man, ≈øo long as he is heere vpon earth, which ≈øuffereth not his hell; nay all the elements, all liuing creatures, all the Diuels, yea the Angels, and God him≈øelfe doe al≈øo bend and band them≈øelues again≈øt man for ≈øinne.
To begin with the ≈øence of feeling: with how many kinds of Feauers, Impo≈øtumes, Vlcers, Sores, is the bodie afflicted?

The volumes of Phy≈øicke are full of di≈øea≈øes, and of the di≈øcouery of the probable remedies for the ≈øame, and yet for all this, there are daily new di≈øea≈øes, and new (yet but coniectured remedies) found out for many of them; and Phy≈øitions know not what to make of ≈øome of them. The Sea will haue his fluxe, and Death will haue his cour≈øe, they both keepe their old wont. Since the fir≈øt diui≈øion of waters, the Sea hath beene accu≈øtomed to ebbe and flow; who hath euer hindered it? And ≈øince the fir≈øt corruption of Nature, Death hath beene accu≈øtomed to ≈ølay and de≈øtroy; who hath re≈øi≈øted it? Other cu≈øtomes haue and may be aboli≈øhed; a King may command, and it is done: but what Monarch ≈øo ab≈øolute, what Emperour ≈øo potent, that can abrogate within his Dominions this cu≈øtome of dying?

Nay, there is no priuiledge, no not ≈øpirituall, neither can that grace and excellent gift of holine≈ø≈øe and pietie, pre≈øerue a man from a naturall death (viz. the fir≈øt death) out of no Court or Church can a man fetch a writ of protection again≈øt this Sergeant, no place will pre≈øerue, no per≈øon can bee priuiledged from it. E≈øay 57.1. For heere the holy and good man, the righteous and religious man, is taken from the earth and dieth. Iames 1.18. For if any ≈øhould be ≈øpared, he that is begotten againe of Gods owne will by the word of truth, he that is borne againe of water and of the Spirit, Iohn 3.5. and ≈øo borne not of bloud, nor of the will of the fle≈øh, Ioh. 1.13. nor of the will of man, but of God. He that is borne a new, not of mortall ≈øeed, but of immortall by the word of God, 1. Pet. 1.23. which liueth and endureth
for euer. A man (I ≈øay) would thinke that ≈øuch (if any) ≈øhould not die; and yet behold the whole generation of Gods children, they all die in their appointed time, and vndergoe death, not as a puni≈øhment, but as a tribute (as Seneca the Heathen man ≈øpeakes) which euery man mu≈øt pay for his life. The foole dies, the wi≈øe-man, the ≈øubiect, the Soueraigne. I haue ≈øaid (≈øaith the P≈øalmi≈øt) yee are gods, P≈øal. 49.10. P≈øal. 82.6.7. and yee all are children of the mo≈øt high, but yee ≈øhall die as a man, and yee Princes ≈øhall fall like others: and ≈øo al≈øo the Prophets and holy men of God: Dauid was a man after Gods owne heart, and yet he died: Mo≈øes ≈øaw God face to face, and yet he died: Zach. 1.5. The Prophets were indued with a great mea≈øure of ≈øanctification, yet the Prophet Zachary ioynes them all together in one ≈øtate of mortalitie. Your Fathers, where are they? And doe the Prophets liue for euer? What ≈øay I, the Prophets? Nay Chri≈øt Ie≈øus him≈øelfe the Sonne of God, the onely Sonne, the Sonne in whom he was well plea≈øed, more faithfull then Abraham, more righteous then Iob, more wi≈øe then Salomon, more mightie then Sam≈øon, more holy then Dauid and all the Prophets, though hee knew no ≈øinne in him≈øelfe, yet for taking on him the burthen of our ≈øinnes, became ≈øubiect to the ≈øame condition of mortalitie with vs, and he died al≈øo.

Examples of other times, experience of our owne teach vs that all of all ≈øorts die, and are gathered to their fathers, yea the dumbe and dead bodies cry this aloud vnto vs. As Ba≈øil of Seleucia ≈øaith of Noah, he preached without words of Preaching; for euery ≈øtroake vpon the Arke was a reall Sermon of repentance, ≈øo euery corp≈øe that wee follow and accompany to the graue, preacheth really this truth vnto vs. All the worthie≈øt of the fir≈øt times and whom≈øoeuer el≈øe the word of God hath well reported of, where are they? Are they not all dead? Doe they not all ≈øee corruption? (our Sauiour Chri≈øt excepted). Are they not all gone downe into the ≈ølimie valley? Haue they not long ≈øince made their bed in the darke? None of them all (our Sauiour Chri≈øt
excepted) was able to deliuer his life from the power of the graue. Art thou better then Dauid, and wi≈øer then Salomon? Nay, art thou greater then our Father Abraham, who is dead, and the Prophets which are dead? Whom make≈øt thou thy ≈øelfe? If thou thinke≈øt thou ≈øhoulde≈øt not die; Then ≈øurely if the holie≈øt begotten and borne of man doe die, then all mu≈øt die. And if holine≈ø≈øe mu≈øt yeeld, then prophanene≈ø≈øe cannot ≈øtand out. And therfore whether holy or prophane, Iew or Greeke, bond or free, male or female, all mu≈øt die. If the tender harted woman that wept for Chri≈øt, then the ≈øtony hearted men that ≈øcoffed at Chri≈øt. If tho≈øe that imbalmed him, then tho≈øe that buffeted him. If ≈øhee that powred oyntment on his head, then he that ≈øpat in his face. If Iohn his beloued Apo≈øtle, then Iudas that betrayed him.

Man is a little world, the world a great man, if the great man mu≈øt die, how ≈øhall the little one e≈øcape? We mu≈øt not thinke much to vndergoe that, which all are enioyned vnto nece≈ø≈øarily. Equalitie is the chiefe ground-worke of equitie, and who can complaine to be comprehended, where all are contained. For there is not a ≈øonne of man in the clu≈øter of mankinde, but Eodem modo & nodo, vinctus & victus, is liable to that common and equal law of Death. And although they die not one death for time and manner, yet for the matter and end, one death is infallible to all the ≈øonnes of men. Lift vp your eyes to the heauens (≈øaith the Lord) and looke vpon the earth beneath, E≈øay 51.6. for the heauens ≈øhal vani≈øh away like ≈ømoake, and the earth ≈øhall waxe old like a garment, and they that dwell therein ≈øhall die in like manner. But if any ≈øhall obiect that Enoch and Elias died not. Gen. 23.24. Hebr. 11.6. 2. King. 2.11. I an≈øwere, We know not. I rather thinke they did, and that Elias in his fiery Chariot had his body burnt, and Enoch, who in his yeares matched the dayes of the Sunne 365. was without paine di≈ø≈øolued, when God tooke his ≈øoule to heauen; or if they died not, yet (as Origen ≈øaith) the generall is not therefore fal≈øe, becau≈øe God hath di≈øpenced in ≈øome particulers, though one or two died not, yet this is an vniuer≈øall truth of all men to be receiued,
and duely pondered. Heb. 9.21. It is appointed vnto all men that they ≈øhall once die, from which there is no auoidance. For the Lord of life and death hath ≈øo decreed it; the decree was made in the beginning: Gen. 3.19. For du≈øt thou art, and to du≈øt thou ≈øhalt returne. If it be his decree, it mu≈øt needs haue a certaine effect. The decree is certaine, the euent is ineuitable. Our God (≈øaith the P≈øalmi≈øt) P≈øal. 115.3. is in heauen, and hee doth what≈øoeuer hee will. Gods will is the deede (as ≈øaith Saint Cyprian) if he hath once willed it, it is as good as wrought. If he haue decreed it, it is as certaine as if it were done. It is heauens decree, and it cannot be reuoked.Dan. 6.1.

I haue beene ≈øomewhat too tedious in this fir≈øt Diui≈øion, which is ≈øomwhat contrarie to the common prouerbe, that he ≈øhould not be tedious that reades a Lecture of mortality, but becau≈øe this is on the one ≈øide a matter worthy to be ob≈øerued: and on the other≈øide, a matter too too much neglected, I haue beene ≈øomewhat the bolder to in≈øi≈øt the longer vpon it. And therefore to conclude with my Statute. It is appointed &c.

It is therefore a care that euery one ought to haue, viz. to know that they mu≈øt die, and that they cannot auoid it. The decree is gone out again≈øt them, from the highe≈øt court of Parliament of the mo≈øt High. What contempt were it not to take notice of it?

Euery one therfore ought to labour to number his daies, and truely to know his mortalitie, the greate≈øt as well as the meane≈øt, the wi≈øe≈øt as the ≈øimple≈øt. For if any one, then all, and if any more then other, then the greate≈øt, for the greate≈øt are mo≈øt ≈øubiect to death. As they challenge them≈øelues to be the fine≈øt of the common mould, ≈øo they mu≈øt know, that, by that they are not exempted from the common law of Nature, and force of Gods decree. But as, the finer the mettall, or the purer the matter of any gla≈ø≈øe or earthen ve≈ø≈øell is, the more ≈øubiect it is to breaking, and ≈øo the daintie≈øt bodies the ≈øoone≈øt gone. It behoueth vs all therefore to ≈øeeke for ≈øpirituall Arithmeticke, thereby to number
our dayes in a religious meditation of the incertainties of the time and the certaintie that that time will come. Let vs therefore liue to die, yea liue the life of grace, that wee may liue the life of glory. And then though we mu≈øt go to the dead, yet we ≈øhall ri≈øe from the dead, and from thenceforth liue with our God out of the reach of Death for euermore.
div.trailer: The end of the fir≈øt Diui≈øion.

div.head: THE SECOND DIVISION, ON THE MEDITATION OF DEATH.
div.p:
THen if Death be thus certaine, in the next place the law of rea≈øon adui≈øeth vs to thinke of the worlds vanitie to contemne it, of death to expect it, of iudgement to auoid it, of hell to e≈øcape it, and of heauen to de≈øire it. And thinke it not needle≈ø≈øe or ≈øuperfluous to bee exhorted to this Meditation; that the ignorant may learne, the carele≈ø≈øe con≈øider, and the forgetfull remember that they all mu≈øt die. For, as Saint Augu≈øtine ≈øaith, nothing ≈øo recalleth a man from ≈øinne, as the frequent remembrance of death. For the error of all men, for the mo≈øt part, taketh his originall from hence, that they forget the end of their life, which they ought alwayes to haue before their eyes. And of the want of this commeth pride, ambition, vaine-glory, too much carefulne≈ø≈øe of the body, too much carking and caring after the things of this life. Hence al≈øo it commeth that we build Towers vpon the ≈øand. For if wee did con≈øider what we ≈øhall be after a few dayes, our manner of liuing would perhaps bee more humble, temperate and godly,: for who would haue a high looke, P≈øal. 131.1. and a proud ≈øtomacke, if hee did with the eyes of his minde behold what
manner of one he ≈øhortly after ≈øhall be in his graue? who would then wor≈øhip his belly for a god, Phil. 3.19. when he waigheth with him≈øelfe that the ≈øame mu≈øt in ≈øhort time be wormes meate? who would be ≈øo in loue with money, that he would runne like a mad-man by ≈øea and land (as it were through fire and water) if he vnder≈øtood that he mu≈øt leaue all behinde him?

If this were well thought vpon, our errors would ≈øoone be corrected, and our liues bettered. Wi≈øh therefore rather for a good, then a long life. It is a thing doubtle≈ø≈øe, worthy of euery mans be≈øt thoughts and intentions. For ≈øeeing euery man mu≈øt die, and hath a cour≈øe to fini≈øh, which being fini≈øhed, hee mu≈øt away. It is ≈øpeciall wi≈ødome to learne to know the length of his dayes, as it were the length of his lea≈øe: for as he hath v≈øed him≈øelfe in his farme, he ≈øhall enter at the expiration of his time vpon a better or a wor≈øe.

1. Sam. 13.14. Dauid for his learning a Prophet, for his acceptation, a man after Gods owne heart, for his authority a King, was then very ≈øtudious in this knowledge, when after fa≈øting and watching, he be≈øought God to be in≈øtructed in it. Lord let me know my end, P≈øal. 39.4. and the mea≈øure of my dayes, what it is, let me know how long I haue to liue. Act. 7.22. So Mo≈øes, wi≈øe in all the wi≈ødome of Egypt and I≈ørael, accounted faithfull in the hou≈øe of God, Heb. 3.2. prayed yet for this point of wi≈ødome to be informed in it, P≈øal. 90.12. and as well for him≈øelfe as others. Teach vs ≈øo to number our daies (≈øaith he) that we may apply our hearts vnto wi≈ødome: like carefull ≈øchollers, who for≈øake their meat and drinke, and breake their ≈øleepe, and are often in meditation when they beate vpon ≈øome ≈øerious ≈øubiect.

What thinke you it will profit a man, if by his skill in Arithmetike, hee be able to deale with euery number, and to diuide the lea≈øt fractions, and neuer to thinke on the numbering of his daies with the men of God, and yet his dayes are few and euill?

What will it profit him, if by Geometrie hee bee able to take the longitude of mo≈øt ≈øpatious pro≈øpects, and not be
able to mea≈øure that which the Prophet hath mea≈øured with his ≈øpanne?P≈øal. 39.51.

What will it auaile him, if with the a≈øtronomer he be able to ob≈øerue and know the motions of the heauens, and yet haue his heart ≈øo buried in the earth, that hee cannot thinke of that which pa≈ø≈øeth away as ≈øwiftly as any motion of them all?

What profiteth it (I ≈øay) If he be able, with the Philo≈øopher, to ≈øearch out the cau≈øes of many effects, and to know the cau≈øes of many changes, as of the ebbing and flowing of the ≈øeas the increa≈øing and wayning of the Moone, and the like, and be not able to know his owne changes, and the cau≈øes of them? Doubtle≈ø≈øe all this wil profit them nothing, all this knowledge will be to little purpo≈øe in the end. And vnle≈ø≈øe they think vpon death, they cannot apply and fa≈øhion them≈øelues to a godly life. Yea we finde daily by experience, that the forgetfulne≈ø≈øe of death maketh vs applie our hearts to all kinde of folly and vanity.

The holy men in old time were wont to keepe ≈øuch an account of their dayes, and ≈øo to think on death, that aboue all things they might apply their hearts vnto wi≈ødome. So mindfull of the≈øe things was Saint Ierome, who ≈øaith of him≈øelfe, that whether he did eate or drinke, or what≈øoeuer el≈øe he did, he thought alwaies this ≈øound of the la≈øt trumpet did euer ring in his eares. Ari≈øe yee dead, and come to iudgement. Which when I con≈øider (≈øaith he) it makes me ≈øhake and quake and not dare to commit ≈øinne, which otherwi≈øe I ≈øhould haue committed.

Likewi≈øe that ancient and reuerend father Innocentius the fourth, was ≈øo carefull to auoid the vengeance to come that to ≈øtirre vp all the powers and faculties of his minde, with due con≈øideration of the vanitie of this world, the vilene≈ø≈øe of his nature, the ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe of his time, the cau≈øes of ≈øinne, and the puni≈øhment for the ≈øame, he ≈øtill imagined to heare a damned ≈øoule an≈øwere his demand, as followeth, in manner of an interlocution or dialogue.
Thou du≈øt and clay, tell me (I ≈øay) where is thy bewtie fled?
Was it in vaine, or doth it giue thee fauour with the dead?
Thy hou≈øe ≈øo high, thy plea≈øures by, thy cattell more and le≈ø≈øe,
Thy land ≈øo wide, thy wife be≈øide a ≈øtranger doth po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe.
Where is thy ≈øtrength become at length, thy wit, thy noble blood,
Thy worldly care, thy daintie faire, doe the≈øe thee any good?
The an≈øwere.
I will not faine, all is but vaine, there is no food to find,
No wit, nor wealth, no hire, no health, no hope in graue a≈ø≈øign'd:
What wilt thou more? my goods in ≈øtore, my land ≈øo large & wide,
My glory gay, my braue aray, increa≈øed haue my pride.
My pride my paine procur'd againe, my paine, my griefe, alas,
My griefe, my griefe, without reliefe, my ≈øences doth ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe.
My wailing woe no man doth know, no tongue can halfe di≈øplay;
I freeze, I frie exceedingly, alas, and well away.
I weepe, I wayle, I faint, I faile, I ≈øtirre, I ≈øtampe, I ≈øtare,
I dye, I dye, e'rela≈øtingly, farewell, by me beware.
Remember thou learn'd that die thou mu≈øt,
And after come to iudgement iu≈øt.
Behold thy ≈øelfe by me, ≈øuch one was I, as thou,
And thou in time ≈øhall be euen du≈øt, as I am now.

And ≈øo mindefull hereof al≈øo was Anaxagoras; for when word was brought vnto him, that his ≈øonne was dead, hee was not much moued with the newes, becau≈øe (as he ≈øaid) he knew, and had well con≈øidered, long before, that his ≈øon was mortall. For a mortall father cannot beget an immortall ≈øonne. If they that brought vs into the world are gone out of the world them≈øelues, wee may infallibly conclude our owne following. Hee that may ≈øay I haue a man to my father, a woman to my mother in this life, may in death ≈øay with Iob, Iob 17.14. To corruption, thou art my father, to the worme, thou art my mother and my ≈øi≈øter.

Xerxes that mighty Monarch and Emperor of the Per≈øians,
(beholding from a high place) the hugene≈ø≈øe of his Army, in ≈øtrength inuincible, in quality diuers, in number infinite, in who≈øe courage and might he had fully repo≈øed the ≈øtrength of his Kingdome, the ≈øafegard of his per≈øon, and glory of his Empire, could not refraine his eyes from teares, con≈øidering that of all this maruelous multitude which hee ≈øaw, that after one hundred yeares, there ≈øhould not a man be left. And ≈øhall we that are Chri≈øtians, (at lea≈øt wi≈øe by name) viewing from the highe≈øt pinnacle of our conceit, our ≈øelues, our glory, magnificence and renowne, our wealth, our ≈øtrength, our freinds, our health, and all our brauery, wherein we repo≈øe all our felicity and happine≈ø≈øe, be nothing moued with the due con≈øideration of our Death, and with the pa≈ø≈øing away of the world, and the concupi≈øcence thereof? Therefore ≈øaith Martial an antient Bi≈øhop, what haue we to doe with the delight of the world, that it ≈øhould hinder vs from the meditation on Death? You may call it as you will, either plea≈øure, pa≈øtime, gladne≈ø≈øe, mirth, ioy: but in Gods dictionary it hath no ≈øuch name, in the holy ≈øcripture it is otherwi≈øe called. It is called Adams goodlie apple, Gen. 3.17. Gen. 25.30. 1 Sam. 14 43. Ioh. 13.27. Reu. 1. Luk. 15.16. which being eaten, depriued him of paradi≈øe. E≈øaus redde broath, which being ≈øupt vp bereaued him of his birthright. Ionathans ≈øweete honycombe, which being but ta≈øted, was like to co≈øt him his life. Thus is all the delight in the world called in Gods dictionarie. It is called Adams apple, E≈øaus broath, Ionathans hony-combe. So that all this delight is no delight, or ≈øuppo≈øe it were, yet certainely it ≈øhall not giue thee the de≈øires of thy heart.

As any ≈øolide body, though it haue neuer ≈øo faire a colour, as crim≈øon, or cornation, or purple, or ≈øcarlet, or violet, or ≈øuch like, yet alwaies the ≈øhadow of it is black, ≈øo any earthly thing, though it haue neuer ≈øo faire a ≈øhew yet alwaies the ≈øhadow of it is blacke, and the delight thou take≈øt in it ≈øhall prooue to be grieuous in the end when thou mu≈øt leaue all. Therefore Plato calleth it a ≈øweete bitter thing; ≈øo likewi≈øe if we meditate on Death, it will make vs to call all the≈øe
things of the world not ≈øweet but bitter. And it would make vs ≈øay with the Apo≈øtle, Gal. 6.14. God forbid that I ≈øhould delight in any thing but in the cro≈ø≈øe and death of Chri≈øt by which the world is crucified vnto me, and I vnto the world.

But of all arithmeticall rules, this is the harde≈øt, to number our daies. Men can number their heards and droues of Oxen and ≈øheepe, they can account the reuenues of their lands and farmes, they can with a little paines number their coyne and gaines, & yet they are per≈øwaded that their daies are infinit and innumerable, and therefore they neuer begin to number, nor thinke on them for the which they will neuer find any lea≈øure. Who ≈øaith not vpon the view of another; ≈øurely yonder man looketh by his countenance as if he would not liue long, yonder woman is old, her daies cannot be many? Thus we can number the dayes and yeares of others, and vtterly forget our owne. But the true wi≈ødome of mortall men is to number their owne daies, and like skilfull Geometricians to mea≈øure all their actions, all their ≈øtudies, all their cares and indeauours, all their thoughts and de≈øires, and all their coun≈øells by their departure out of this life (as the end whereunto they are re≈øerued) as it were by a certaine rule, and thereunto to direct all things, and ≈øo to fini≈øh the cour≈øe of our life which God hath giuen vs, that at la≈øt we may come to the hauen of eternall re≈øt and happine≈ø≈øe.

What if we had dyed in the dayes of ignorance, like Iudas that hanged him≈øelfe before he could ≈øee the pa≈ø≈øion, re≈øurrection, or a≈øcen≈øion of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt? We ≈øhould then haue numbred our daies and our ≈øinnes too. But ala≈ø≈øe how many dayes haue we ≈øpent, and yet neuer thought why one day was giuen vs? But as the old yeare went, and an other came, ≈øo we thought that a new would follow that, and ≈øo we thinke that another will follow this, and God knoweth how ≈øoone wee ≈øhall be deceiued. For ≈øo thought many of them before, who are now in their graues.

Dearely beloued, this is not to number our dayes, but to
prouoke God to ≈øhorten our dayes. I that write, you that read, and all that heare this, which of vs hath not liued twenty yeeres, yea ≈øome forty, fiftie, or more, and yet wee haue neuer ≈øeriou≈øly thought on Death, nor applyed our hearts aright vnto wi≈ødome. O if we had learned but euery yeere one vertue, ≈øince wee were borne, we might by this time haue bene like Saints among≈øt men, whereas if God at this pre≈øent time ≈øhould call vs to iudgment, it would appeare that we had applyed our hearts, mindes, memories, hands, feete, tongues, and all our whole bodies to all kinde of ≈øinne and wickedne≈ø≈øe, but not applyed our ≈øelues at all to wi≈ødome, godline≈ø≈øe, vertue, and true piety.

Democritus was wont to walke among≈øt the graues, that he might become a right Philo≈øopher; for true philo≈øophie (≈øaith Plato) is the meditation on death; and thou which art in≈øtructed in the true Chri≈øtian Philo≈øophie, how can≈øt thou behold the bones of the dead, but thou mu≈øt needs fall into this patheticall meditation with thy ≈øelfe. Behold the≈øe legges that haue made ≈øo many iourneyes, this head which is the receptacle of wi≈ødome, & remembreth ≈øo many things, mu≈øt ≈øhortly be as this bare skull and dry bones are. I will therefore betimes bid worldly vanities adieu, betake my ≈øelfe to repentance, and newne≈ø≈øe of life, and ≈øpend the re≈øt of my dayes in the ≈øeruice of my God, and continuall meditation on my ende.

Wee can be content to liue ≈øeuen yeeres Apprenti≈øe with great labour and toile, to bee in≈øtructed in ≈øome trade, that we may liue the more ea≈øily the re≈øt of our dayes; and about this we ≈øpend our thoughts and meditations, and cannot we then be well contented to labour a little while in the matters of our ≈øaluatioÃÑ, & ≈øpend our thoughts, endeauours and meditations therein, that we may re≈øt from all our labours for euer after in heauen.

Matth. 26.40. Our Sauiour Chri≈øt ≈øaid vnto his Di≈øciples, when he had found them ≈øleeping, What, could yee not watch one houre? And ≈øo I ≈øay vnto all men, What, can you not meditate on Death ≈øome few houres?

Which meditation on Death we mu≈øt not make a naked di≈øcour≈øe, or bare reading onely, but a vehement application of the minde to the thing it ≈øelfe, with an inward ≈øence and feeling of the heart, all the di≈øtractions of our thoughts being abandoned. For meditation is an action or worke of the ≈øoule, bending it ≈øelfe often, earne≈øtly, and orderly to think vpon a thing; and it is either of Gods word or works, and Death is one of Gods workes, euen a worke of mercy, to his elect and cho≈øen children, but a work of iu≈øtice to the vngodly and reprobate. Therefore that thou maye≈øt meditate profitably on Death, whereby it may proue a worke of Gods mercie vnto thee, put thy ≈øelfe humbly in the ≈øight of God, who beholdeth thee in all thy actions, and thus pre≈øent, begge of him, that all thy thoughts, words and works,
yea and all thy meditations, may wholly be guided and directed to his glory, and thy owne ≈øaluation, and intreate thy God with heartie affections to giue thee grace that thou maye≈øt take profit by the con≈øideration, and the meditation of thy la≈øt end. And let vs not imitate fooli≈øh men, who looke and thinke vpon pre≈øent things only, but let vs meditate on things to come; and ≈øo by the grace of God we ≈øhall bring to pa≈ø≈øe that the ≈øame houre, which to others that are incon≈øiderate, is the beginning of ≈øorrowes and mi≈øeries, to vs ≈øhall be the entrance into all ioy and happine≈ø≈øe.

div.head: THE THIRD DIVISION, OF THE PREPARATION FOR DEATH.
div.p: NOw by way of preparation vnto death, let vs ob≈øerue that the greate≈øt worke we haue to fini≈øh in this world is to die well; & they which die well die not to die, but to liue eternally. That man doth fini≈øh his daies in his be≈øt ≈øort, that euery day e≈øteemeth the la≈øt day of his life to be pre≈øent or neere at hand, and that a man may die well, Gods word requireth a preparation for Death.

The Preparation for death is an action of a repentant ≈øinner, whereby he makes him≈øelfe fit and ready euery day to leaue this life, and to die well. And it is a dutie very nece≈ø≈øarie, and of great waight and importance, to which we are tied and bound by Gods Commandement, and therefore it can in no wi≈øe bee omitted of him, that de≈øires to make a happie and ble≈ø≈øed end.

Wherefore this preparation is two-fold, Generall and particular. Generall preparation is that whereby a man prepares him≈øelfe to die, through the whole cour≈øe of his life. The rea≈øons are the≈øe, viz.

Fir≈øt, Death which is certaine, is mo≈øt vncertaine; I ≈øay it is certaine, becau≈øe no man can auoid it: and it is vncertaine three wayes. Fir≈øt, in regard of the time, for no man doth know when he ≈øhall die. Secondly, in regard of the place, becau≈øe no man knoweth where he ≈øhall die: and thirdly, in
regard of the kind of death, for that no man knowes whether he ≈øhall die of an ordinary or extraordinary death, whether of a lingring or ≈øodaine death, whether ea≈øie or violent. Therefore from thence it followes that we ≈øhould euery day and in all places prepare our ≈øelues for death.

Indeede if wee could know when, where, and how wee ≈øhould dye, the ca≈øe were otherwi≈øe; but ≈øeeing we know none of all the≈øe, but are ignorant therof, therfore it ≈øtands vs greatly in hand to looke about vs to prepare our ≈øelues for our latter end.

A ≈øecond rea≈øon ≈øeruing further to per≈øwade vs to the performing of this duety, is this, that the mo≈øt dangerous thing in all the world to the hazard of our ≈øoules, is to neglect this preparation. It mu≈øt not be put off till ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, for then it will be vnfitting by rea≈øon of the paine, and of other lets and hinderances at that time. It mu≈øt not be put off to bee done when we will, for it is not in the power of man, to doe this duetie at his plea≈øure, but when God will. Ier. 10.23. O Lord ≈øaith the Prophet) I know that the way of man is not in him≈øelfe, it is not in man (that walketh) to direct his ≈øteps.

And againe, this late preparation, which con≈øi≈øteth chiefly in repentance, is ≈øeldome or neuer true: It is ≈øicke like the partie him≈øelfe, commonly langui≈øhing and dying together with vs. This preparation ≈øhould bee voluntary (as all obedience to God ought to bee) but preparation taken vp in ≈øickne≈ø≈øe is v≈øually con≈øtrained and extorted by the feare of hell, and other iudgements of God. For in true and ≈øound preparation (wherein chiefely wee mu≈øt repent) men mu≈øt for≈øake all their ≈øinnes, but in this, the ≈øin for≈øakes the man, who leaues all his euill wayes only vpon this that he is con≈øtrained, whether he will or no, to leaue the world.

Therefore ponder with thy ≈øelfe, what then thou woulde≈øt that thou hade≈øt done, when being neere vnto death, thou ha≈øt no more time to liue, and the ≈øame thing which thou woulde≈øt wi≈øh thou hade≈øt done, when thou art at the point of death, the ≈øame thing without delay doe, while thou
art in health, that thou mai≈øt be ready euery houre to imbrace the me≈ø≈øage of Death, as Seneca per≈øwades. Mors vbique nos expectat, tu ≈øi ≈øapiens eris vbique eam expectabis, ≈øo it ≈øhall neuer take thee at any aduantage. To this end remember Augu≈øtus his admonition, be afraid to liue in ≈øuch an e≈øtate, as thou art afraid to dy in. And pray vnto God that by his grace the≈øe things may penetrate into the bottom of thy heart, and bee there ≈øo fixed, that they may neuer bee quenched; and that from this time forward thou mai≈øt make ≈øuch v≈øe of the preaching and hearing of his holy word, of the comfortable ≈øacraments of his Church, and all other the good meanes of thy ≈øaluation that thou mai≈øt begin to walke now with a better con≈øcience before him, that in the peace of a quiet con≈øcience (after this preparation) thou mai≈øt thereby arriue at the heauen of eternall glory and happines, and ≈øay with the ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle. Act. 24.16. Herein doe I exerci≈øe my ≈øelfe to haue alwaies a good con≈øcience void of offence toward God and toward men.

Thus then this poynt being manife≈øt, that a generall preparation mu≈øt be made, let vs now ≈øee in what manner it mu≈øt be done. And for the right doing of it fiue duties mu≈øt be practi≈øed in the whole cour≈øe of our liues. The fir≈øt is the meditation on Death; for the life of a Chri≈øtian is nothing el≈øe (as was noted) at large in the ≈øecond diui≈øi ‚Ä¢ n; but a meditation on Death; A notable practi≈øe whereof we haue in the example of Io≈øeph of Arimathia, Mat. 27.60. who made his tombe in his life time in the mid≈øt of his garden, to this end (no doubt) to put him≈øelfe in minde daily of his death, and that in the mid≈øt of his delights and plea≈øant walkes, hee might be the better prepared for Death.

And in this re≈øpect a decent funerall is a dutie to be performed, and a debt to be pa ‚Ä¢ d to the bodies of all Chri≈øtians, who are the temples of the holy gho≈øt, and members of the body of Chri≈øt, 1. Cor. 6.19. Eph. 5.30. and therefore are to be laid with honor into their graues, as into how≈øes of ≈øafe cu≈øtody and beds of re≈øt, to remaine there in peace, vntill the re≈øurrection, to the
end that thereby all others might be admoni≈øhed to meditate hereon, to prepare them≈øelues for their end. Gen. 23. Gen. 25 9. Gen. 50. And therefore did not onely the fathers in the old te≈øtament, but the faithfull al≈øo in the new, performe funerals for their friends departed this life. So Abraham performes a funera ‚Ä¢ l for Sarah, I≈øaac and I≈ømael for Abraham, Io≈øeph, Num. 20.29. Deut. 34.8. the I≈øraelites and the Egiptians a mo≈øt ≈øumptuous one for Iacob, and all I≈ørael at two times kept a ≈øolemne mourning thirtie dayes together for Aaron and Mo≈øes. In the new te≈øtament Iohn the Bapti≈øt is buried and intombed of his di≈øciples. Mat. 14.12. Mark. 15.43. Our Sauiour Chri≈øt by two great Coun≈øellers. And Stephen is carried out to be buried by men fearing God, who made great lamentation for him. And likewi≈øe all the re≈øt of the Patriarches and holy men of God.

This honor is to be giuen vnto the dead, which from the Church was deriued vnto the very gentiles with whom to violate the ≈øepulchers of the dead, was euer accounted an hainous offence, and the place of buriall ≈øacred. But God threatneth it is a iudgment to the wicked that they ≈øhall not be buried and lamented, and denounceth it twice as a great cur≈øe again≈øt Iehoiakin the ≈øonne of Io≈øiah that hee ≈øhall bee buried as an A≈ø≈øe is buried, Ier. 16.4.6. Ier 22 18.19. Ier. 36.30. and that his dead body ≈øhall be ca≈øt out with contempt without any pompe or decencie of buriall.

It appeares al≈øo in Ezechiel that it was a cu≈øtome in old time to enterre valiant men in their armes, Ezech. 32.27. to put them into their graues with weapons of warre, and to bury them with their ≈øwords vnder their heads, which thing God ≈øeemes there to threaten that his enemies ≈øhall not haue; giuing vs thereby to vnder≈øtand that the hauing of ≈øuch funerall pome and ceremonies is an honor a worldly ble≈ø≈øing and a gift of God of which he depriues his enemies, and therefore threatens in the next ver≈øe that they ≈øhall ly by them that are ≈ølaine wi ‚Ä¢ h the ≈øword, that is, ≈øhall not be honorably enterred like Conquerors, but ba≈øely buried among≈øt the conquered.

And although the wicked doe come to this honor of ≈øumptuous funerals, and to be laid in co≈øtly and painted tombes and ≈øepulchers (as it often falleth out) yet it may be ≈øaid of ≈øuch a one, that he which was not long ≈øince clad in ≈øilke, purple, and gold, and ≈øhined with diamonds, is now a≈ø≈øaulted with troupes of wormes, and breathes forth intollerable ≈øents; while that his heire liueth plea≈øantly in ryot and exce≈ø≈øe, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing the fruite of his labours which hee him≈øelfe neuer, or a ≈ømall time enioyed. And herein his very du≈øt and corruption doth appeare, and his ambition, and pride doth re≈øt it ≈øelfe within this tombe; for then behold ≈øtately Sepulchers, engrauen ≈øtones, that report ≈øome famous actions, and proud titles vpon his tombe, ≈øet out with fal≈øe narrations, to the end that pa≈ø≈øengers may ≈øay here lyeth a goodly ≈øtone, but a corrupted bodie.

But the v≈øe that wee mu≈øt make of all burialls and funerals for whom≈øoeuer they be, is to admoni≈øh and put vs in minde, that we mu≈øt make preparation for our owne end, and for the felicitie & happines of the life to come. Which kinde of preparation is of e≈øpeciall v≈øe and brings forth many excellent fruits in the life of man. For a worldling ≈øurfeted with vanities, a proud man in the mid≈øt of his a≈øpiring thoughts, the couetous man in the dogs-hunger of his auarice, the voluptuous man in the fury of his fornication, the enuious man in the torment of his malice, if they can be ≈øo happie as once to prepare them≈øelues for Death in a holy meditation, into what amazement will they be brought to con≈øider of their wondrous folly in their dangerous e≈øtate? Then pride will ≈øtrike her ≈øailes, couetou≈ønes will be ≈øati≈øfied, voluptuo≈øne≈ø≈øe more continent, and enuie more charitable, Gen. 18.27. Iob. 42.6. it will make vs ≈øay with Abraham, I am but du≈øt and a≈øhes; and with the holy man Iob, to abhor our ≈øelues, and to repent in du≈øt and a≈øhes.

The ≈øecond dutie in this generall preparation, is that euery man mu≈øt daily indeauor to take away from his owne Death the power and ≈øting thereof. Iudg. 16.5. The Phili≈øtimes ≈øaw by
experience that Sam≈øon was of great ≈øtrength, and therefore they v≈øed meanes to know in what part of his body his ≈øtrength lay ‚Ä¢ and when they found it to bee in the haire of his head, they neuer cea≈øed practi≈øing with Daliah till it was cut off, and then they had their will of him. In like manner the time will come, when we mu≈øt incounter hand to hand, and grapple with cruell death; and therefore the be≈øt way is before hand, while we haue a breathing time to learne where the ≈øting of Death (which is his ≈øtrength) doth ly, which being once knowne, we mu≈øt with all ≈øpeed cut off his Sam≈øons locks, bereaue him of his power, di≈øarme him, and make him weake and vnable to de≈øtroy vs.

Now to finde out the way, we neede not v≈øe the coun≈øell of any Dalilah, but we haue the oracles and coun≈øels of God, which direct vs plainely, wherein the ≈øtrength and ≈øting of Death con≈øi≈øts, namely in our ≈øinnes, 1 Cor. 15.56. The ≈øting of Death (≈øaith the Apo≈øtle) is ≈øinne. And ≈øeeing we now know that the power and force of euery mans death doth lye in his owne ≈øinnes, (the wages whereof is death, as the ≈øame Apo≈øtle telleth vs) and the body is to dy becau≈øe of ≈øinne, Rom. 6 23. Rom. 8.10. wee mu≈øt therefore indeauour before Death come vpon vs, to pull out this ≈øting, and take froÃÑ him his power & ≈øtrength by humbling our ≈øelues in the time pre≈øent for all our ≈øinnes pa≈øt, and by turning our ≈øelues to God for the time to come; and to labour to haue our ≈øinnes pardoned and forgiuen by the pretious death and blood-≈øhedding of our Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt; by which meanes, and none other, the power of Death is much rebated. For Chri≈øt dyed not to take away Death (as yet) but to change Death, not to overthrow the being of death, but to plucke out the ≈øting of Death, not quite to ≈øtop vp the graue, but to remoue and quell the victorie of the graue. By which meanes Death cannot now ≈øting them that haue their ≈øinnes forgiuen, nor the graue triumph ouer them.

Death in it ≈øelfe is the way to hell vnto the wicked, but it is altered and changed vnto the children of God by grace,
and is become vnto them a portall, by which the ≈øoule pa≈ø≈øeth out of the fraile body into heauen. In it ≈øelfe Death is as a Sergeant to arre≈øt men, and bring them to iudgment, but to the elect children of God, by the Death of Chri≈øt, it is as the Angell which guided the Apo≈øtle Peter out of pri≈øon, Acts 12. and ≈øets them at liberty, and leads them from the vale of teares into the land of righteou≈ønes; and by this meanes of a mighty and bloudie enemie, is ≈øo far forth made tractable and friendly, that wee may now with comfort encounter with Death, and preuaile, ≈øeeing now it is become a peece of our happines.

Exod. 8.8. Acts 8 24. The mo≈øt notorious & wicked per≈øon wheÃÑ he is in dying, perchance will pray, and (with Pharaoh) de≈øire others ‚Ä¢ o pray for him, and will promi≈øe amendement of life with ≈øolemne prote≈øtations, that if he might liue longer, he would become a practi≈øer of all the good duties of faith, repentance and reformation of life, although God knowes, there be too many that after recouery do with Pharaoh breake this promi≈øe. This therefore is a dutie which you mu≈øt be carefull to doe euery day.

Num. 23.10. Wicked Balaam that fal≈øe Prophet would faine dye the Death of the righteous, Let mee (≈øaith he) dye the death of the righteous, and let my la≈øt end bee like his; buthe by no meanes would liue the life of the righteous. But this preparation will bring thee to liue the life of the righteous, and then no doubt but thou ≈øhalt al≈øo dye the death of the righteous.

The third dutie in our generall preparation, is in this life to enter into the fir≈øt degree of life eternall; for eternall life and happines hath three degrees, one in this life, and that is when a man can truly ≈øay with the Apo≈øtle, Gal. 2.20. I liue, and yet not I, but Chri≈øt liueth in me, and the life which I now liue in the fle≈øh, I liue by faith in the ≈øonne of God, who loued me, and gaue him≈øelfe for me; and this all ≈øuch can ≈øay as doe vnfainedly repent, and beleeue, and that are iu≈øtified from their ≈øinnes, ≈øanctified again≈øt their ≈øinnes, and haue the peace of a good
con≈øcience, with other good gifts and graces of the holie Spirit, being the earne≈øt peny of their ≈øaluation.

The ≈øecond degree is in the end of this life, that is, when the bodie goes to the earth, from whence it came, and the ≈øoule returnes to God that gaue it, and is carried by the angels into Abrahams bo≈øome.

The third degree is in the end of the world, that is, at the re≈øurrection and la≈øt iudgement, when bodie and ≈øoule being reunited together, who were ancient louing familiers, liuing and ≈øuffering together, and from their fir≈øt conuer≈øion did draw together as ≈øweete yoke-fellowes in the Kingdome of grace, doe now ioyntly enter together into the Kingdome of glory. So that the fir≈øt of the≈øe three degrees is in this life into which we mu≈øt enter. For he that will liue in eternal happine≈ø≈øe, mu≈øt fir≈øt begin in this life to ri≈øe out of the graue of ≈øinne, in which by nature he lyes buried, and then liue in newne≈ø≈øe of life by grace.

The fourth dutie in our generall preparation, is to exerci≈øe and inure our ≈øelues in dying by little and little, before we come to that point that we mu≈øt needs die indeed. For he that leaues this world, before the world leaue him, giues Death the hand like a welcome me≈ø≈øenger, and departs in peace. Wherefore as they in open games of actiuitie, as running, ≈øhooting, wre≈øtling and ≈øuch like, long before hand, breath their bodies, and exerci≈øe them≈øelues, that in the day of triall they may winne the game, &c. Euen ≈øo ≈øhould wee beginne to die now while we are liuing, that we may be the better prepared for it when it ≈øhall come indeed.

But ≈øome may heere obiect & ≈øay, how can this be done? The Apo≈øtle Saint Paul doth an≈øwere it in giuing vs direction by his owne example, when he ≈øaith, 1. Cor. 15.31. By our reioycing which wee haue in Christ Ie≈øus our Lord, I die daily. And doutle≈ø≈øe this Apo≈øtle died daily, not only becau≈øe he was often in danger of death by rea≈øon of his calling, but al≈øo becau≈øe in all his dangers and troubles hee inured him≈øelfe to die. For when men doe make the right v≈øe of their afflictions,
and doe with their might endeauour to beare them patiently, humbling them≈øelues, as vnder the Lords cha≈øti≈øement and correction, then they are ≈øaid to begin to die well. And he that would mortifie his greate≈øt ≈øinnes, mu≈øt fir≈øt begin to doe it in his ≈ømalle≈øt ≈øinnes; which being once reformed, he ≈øhall with more ea≈øe be able to ouercome his ma≈øter ≈øinnes. For this is the way to keepe ≈øinne from raigning in our mortall bodies. So likewi≈øe he that would bee able to beare the cro≈ø≈øe of all cro≈ø≈øes, as namely death, which is the end of all cro≈ø≈øes, mu≈øt fir≈øt of all learne to beare ≈ømall cro≈ø≈øes, as ≈øickne≈ø≈øes, di≈øea≈øes, troubles, lo≈ø≈øes, pouertie and the like, which may fitly be tearmed little deathes, and the beginnings of the greater death; with which little deaths we mu≈øt fir≈øt acquaint our ≈øelues, before wee can be able to incounter with great Death. For as one well ≈øaith, Death after the cro≈ø≈øe is the le≈ø≈øe.

The world is ≈øet vnto vs as a hou≈øe, wherein we are but tenants at will; out of which the Lord by ≈øickne≈ø≈øe and cro≈ø≈øes giueth vs warning, and by death determineth his will, and requireth it againe at our hands, and willeth vs thereby to prepare our ≈øelues for a better hou≈øe; and the new hou≈øe for which we are to prepare our ≈øelues is mo≈øt plea≈øant, and not ≈øo fraile, ruinous and weake, as our worldly hou≈øe; for the tiles doe ≈øometimes fall off this hou≈øe, the walles doe reele, the roofe doth drop, the pillars doe leane, the foundation doth ≈øinke; And what are the≈øe, but ≈øo many warnings of the Lord to vs to depart hence, and prepare for a better place? Therfore when thou do≈øt perceiue thy falling haires, thy watering eyes, thy trembling hands, thy weake knees, and thy ≈øtooping bodie; what are the≈øe, but onely the citations of Death, which ≈øeemes to warne thee to prepare to packe vp, that thou mai≈øt with more ea≈øe be able to goe out of this ruinous hou≈øe of thine.

It is a fable, but it hath a good mortall: A certaine man did couenant with Death that he ≈øhould neuer ≈øurprize him at vnawares or ≈øodainly, before that he had fir≈øt ≈øent a me≈ø≈øenger
to him to giue him warning that ≈øhortly hee would arre≈øt him; to which Death a≈ø≈øented, that though he could not alwaies forbeare him, yet before hee did ≈øtrike him, hee would giue him warning. Vpon Deaths promi≈øe thus pa≈øt, this man liued ≈øecure, ≈øpending his time in all maner of riot and exce≈ø≈øe; and when he thoughtfull little of Death, then came Death to take him away; with whom this man expo≈øtulating for breach of promi≈øe: Death in di≈øcharging of his fidelitie, replied, that with none, no not tho≈øe that violate all promi≈øes, had he broken promi≈øe, for (≈øaith he) I haue ≈øent many me≈ø≈øenger vnto you, from time to time, to giue you warning of my comming; thou wa≈øt ≈øixe yeares ≈øince taken with a grieuous Feuer; within the≈øe two yeeres ≈øore troubled with Rhumes and di≈øtillations; ≈øince that, taken with the cough and paine in the head, & then troubled with the con≈øumption of the Lungs: And did I not lately ≈øend my brother Germaine vnto thee, the drou≈øie ≈øleeping di≈øea≈øe veturno≈øum ≈øoporem, in which thou did≈øt lye for a while like a dead man? All the≈øe were fore-runners of my comming, to warne thee to make thy ≈øelfe ready for mee, who was neere at hand. Is there any among≈øt vs, that is not ≈øometimes admoni≈øhed of Deathes approaching by ≈øome of the≈øe his Apparators, that hee mu≈øt ≈øhortly depart? The Poet ≈øaith truely:
Mille modis lethi mi≈øeros mors vna fatigat.
A thou≈øand kinds, yet but one death,
Hath death, to take away our breath.

Eccle≈ø. 12.14. Thirdly, the Scripture ≈øaith, That God ≈øhall bring euery work vnto iudgement, with euery ≈øecret thing, whether it be good or euill. Some haue off ‚Ä¢ nded deepely, and haue not beene touched by the Magi≈øtrate: ≈øome haue ≈øuffered great rebuke, and ≈øometimes death, who haue done good, and de≈øerued not only fauour, but recompence, and therefore a day mu≈øt come, and is appointed, wherein the Lord that is iu≈øt, 2. The≈ø≈ø. 1.6.7.8. will recompence tribulation

Fiftly, this is ≈øhadowed out in that Hou≈øholder, Mat. 20.8.10. Matth. 25.19. who wheÃÑ euening was come, called the labourers, and gaue euery man his hire, and peny.

And therefore as the Floud of waters once drowned the world, Gen. 7.1.7. except a few who were ≈øau ‚Ä¢ d in the Arke: ≈øo it is certaine that the floud and tempe≈øt of the la≈øt day with fire ≈øhal con≈øume it, and all therein, 2. But ≈øome will ≈øay, ≈øeeing men come to their account at their death, what needeth any other day of audit or hearing; to whom I an≈øwere, That men at their death receiue but priuate iudgement, but heere they ≈øhall receiue publike ≈øentence, then they are iudged in their ≈øoules onely, heere they ≈øhall be in ≈øoule and body. The Hebrewes, they boa≈øt of the Prophecie of Eliah, a great man in tho≈øe dayes; who prophecied that the world ≈øhould la≈øt ≈øixe thou≈øand yeeres, two thou≈øand before the Law, two thou≈øand vnder the Law, two thou≈øand from

Saint Paul ≈øaith, 1. Cor. 10.11. That wee are they vpon whom the ends of the world are come; If therefore the end of the world were come vpon them that liued aboue one thou≈øand and fiue hundred yeeres agoe, then ≈øurely Doomes day cannot now be farre off.
Saint Iames ≈øaith Iam. 5.9. Behold the Iudge ≈øtandeth before the dore.

Saint Peter ≈øa ‚Ä¢ th, 1. Pet. 4.7. The end of all things is at hand. Though no man can ≈øhew the fingers of this hand.

The Apo≈øtle Saint Iude ≈øaith Iude 1.14.15. And Enoch, the ≈øeuenth al≈øo from Adam prophecied of the≈øe ≈øaying, Behold the Lord commeth with ten thou≈øand of his Saints, to execute iudgement vpon all, and to conuince all that are vngodly among them, of all their vngodly deeds, which they haue vngodly committed, and of all their hard ≈øpeeches, which vngodly ≈øinners haue ≈øpoken again≈øt him. That the great day of the Lords wrath is come, not will come as if tha ‚Ä¢ had bin come a thou≈øand and fiue hunddred yeeres agoe, that is not come yet.
The like ≈øpeech we haue in the Prophecie of E≈øay, I≈øa. 13.9. Behold the day commeth, when it was further off.
In the time of the Prophet Zephany it is ≈øaid, Zeph. 1.14. The great day of the Lord is neere, it is neere, and ha≈øteth greatly, euen the voice of the day of the Lord.

And Malachy, the la≈øt of the Prophets, ≈øpeaketh as Enoch, Malac. 4.1. For behold the day commeth that ≈øhall burne as an oven, and all the proud, yea and all that doe wickedly ≈øhall bee ≈øtubble, and the

Of which many, yea almo≈øt all are already fulfilled. And although ≈øome flatter them≈øelues with an imagination of a longer day, theÃÑ God hath ≈øet vnto them, or perhaps vnto the world, for the la≈øt houre therof. (Who are ≈øuch as the Apo≈øtle Saint Peter ≈øpeaketh of, 2. Pet. 3.3.4. That there ≈øhall come in the la≈øt dayes, ≈øcoffers, walking after their owne lu≈øts, and ≈øaying where is the promi≈øe of his comming, for ≈øince the Fathers fell a≈øleepe, all things continue as they were from the beginning of the Creation.) But let ≈øuch know, that though the day of Iudgement were farre off, yet the day and houre of euery mans perticular iudgement in death cannot bee farre off: it being a common and true ≈øaying, 2. Pet. 3.10. To day a man, to morrow none. And vnto ≈øuch then Death doth ≈øpecially come, when they doe lea≈øt thinke of it‚ñ™ euen as a theefe in the night.

Reuel. 3.3. The Sonne of God al≈øo ≈øaith, Behold I will come on thee as a theefe, and thou ≈øhalt not know what houre I will come vpon thee. And theeues haue this propertie, to breake open hou≈øes when men ≈øleepe ≈øoundly ≈øu≈øpecting nothing.

Amos 8.9. The Prophet Amos ≈øaith, It ≈øhall come to pa≈ø≈øe in that day (≈øaith the Lord) that I will cau≈øe the Sun to goe downe at noone, and I will darken the earth in the cleere day. That is to ≈øay, when men thinke it to be the high noone of their age, when they thinke they haue many yeeres yet to liue, and when they ≈øhall ≈øay Peace and ≈øafetie, 1. The≈ø≈ø. 5.3. then ≈øodaine de≈øtruction commeth vpon them, as trauaile vpon a woman with childe, and they ≈øhall not e≈øcape.

Matth. 24.48.49.50.51. And hereupon al≈øo our Sauiour Chri≈øt ≈øaith, But if that euill ≈øeruant ≈øhall ≈øay in his heart my Lord delayeth his comming and ≈øhall begin to ≈ømite his fellow ≈øeruants, and to eat and drinke with the drunken; the Lord of that ≈øeruant ≈øhall come in a day,
when he looketh not for him, and in an houre that he his not aware off, and ≈øhall cut him in ≈øunder, and appoynt him his portion with the hypocrits, There ≈øhall be weeping and gna≈øhing of teeth.

And for the day of the generall death of this langui≈øhing world, hee that wi≈øely con≈øidereth the wayings and declinings that haue beene found in it within the≈øe few yeares, and how like a woman with child (which hath many pangs and fits before the throwes of her great labour come) it is now in paine, till it be deliuered, hauing much complained in tho≈øe ≈øignes and alterations which haue gone before, I ≈øay, that hee that well ob≈øerueth to the true purpo≈øe of his ≈øaluation, the≈øe and ≈øuch like throwes, or rather downe-throwes of things in the wombe of this old and ≈øickly world, ≈øo neere vnto the time of her trauell, and appoynted end by fire, cannot but ≈øay, that it cannot continue longer, and that the Lord will come among≈øt vs very ≈øhortly.

When we ≈øee a man in who≈øe face wearing age hath made many wrincles, and deepe furrowes, we ≈øay this man cannot liue long; ≈øo when we ≈øee the furrowes of old age to appeare and bee manife≈øt in ≈øo many wa≈øtes and con≈øumptions, as this feeble world is entred into, why doe we not ≈øee and conclude that the Death of it is neere.

More particularly and ≈øpecially, as there is no greater ≈øigne that a man is drawing towards death, then when hee alwaies is catching at the ≈øheetes and blanckets, and euer pulling at ≈øomwhat; ≈øo ≈øeing ‚Ä¢ hat euery one catcheth & pulleth all that he can in this griple and couetous age, and that there is ≈øo in≈øatiable a mind of hauing, now in all conditions and callings of people, it is a ≈øure ≈øigne to the heart of a wi≈øe man, that this world is ≈øick euen to death; ≈øo as it cannot hold out long. And if there be no greater ≈øigne of Death then that the body is ≈øo cold, that no heat will come vnto it; Mat. 24.12. Luke 18.8. ≈øurely the cold charitie of the world, mens want of zeale in religion, our nullitie of faith, or poore growth therein) in ≈øo much as good ≈øermons are ≈øeldome heard, and with ≈ømall amendement) the≈øe things cannot but te≈øtifie, that the
world it ≈øelfe can bee of no long life. And if it be ≈øo ≈øhould it not much concerne vs pre≈øently without delay to turne vnto God, to repent, and beleeue the Go≈øpell, to enter into, and keepe the way of truth and vertue, and to prepare our ≈øelues for our end. The rea≈øons why God would not haue vs to know either the generall or particuler day of iudgment are principally the≈øe.

Fir≈øt to proue and try our faith, patience, loue preparation for Death, and other vertues, to ≈øee whether wee will bee con≈øtant in them, till the very day it ≈øelfe ≈øhall come. He that indureth (≈øaith Chri≈øt) Math. 24.13. to the end ≈øhall be ≈øaued.

Secondly as it is the glory of a King to know ≈øomething that no man els can know, ≈øo it is a part of Gods glory to hide fron men and Angels the particular houres of mans death, and this worlds doome, which he hath clo≈øed vp with the ≈øeale of ≈øecrecy, and put in his owne power. In which re≈øpect the wi≈øe man ≈øaith Pro. 25.1. it is the glory of God to conceale a thing. Therfore this is hiddeÃÑ from vs to bridle our curio≈øitie and peeui≈øh inqui≈øition after ≈øuch high and hidden matters aboue our reach and capacity. For it is not in the fadom of mans head to tell, or heart to know how neere or farre off the day is; onely God knoweth, and Chri≈øt as God in what yeare, month, day and moment this frame ≈øhall goe downe. In an age long ≈øince the day was neere; now the houre is neere; but curio≈øitie is to be auoided in a coÃÑcealed matter, & in this forbidden tree of knowledge. Many men beate their heades about friuolous matters, ≈øome (≈øaith Chry≈øo≈øtome) being more bu≈øie to know where hell is, then to auoide the paines of it, others plea≈øing them≈øelues in pelting and needle≈ø≈øe que≈øtions (as this is) to ≈øeeme ≈øingular among≈øt men, neglecting in the meane time this dutie of their preparation for their end, and ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øary things. But when they come to their departing they ≈øhall

It is ≈øufficient for vs therefore to know that ≈øuch a day will come, and it ≈øhall bee wi≈ødome in vs alwaies to bee readie for it, that it come not vpon vs as the ≈ønare vpon the bird vnlooked for. Therefore our Sauiour Chri≈øt ≈øaith, Luk. 12.34.35. take heede to your ≈øelues, le≈øt at any time your hearts be ouercharged with ≈øurfetting and drunkennes and cares of this life, and ≈øo that day come vpon you vnawares; for as a ≈ønare ≈øhall it come on all them that dwell on the face of the earth.

Thirdly if wee knew the day, houre, or certaine time of our death, wee would put off all ti ‚Ä¢ l the comming of that day and it would giue vs too great boldnes and incouragement to wallow in all manner of ≈øinne till that time or houre came.

The whori≈øh woman becau≈øe ≈øhee knew the iu≈øt time when her husband would returne, who went into a farre Countrey, did the more liberally power out her ≈øoule to ≈øinne and wantonne≈ø≈øe. Pro. 7.19.20. For the good man (≈øaith ≈øhee) is not at home, hee is gone along iourney, hee hath taken a bagge of money with him, and will come home at the day appoynted.

Fourthly and la≈øtly. It is therefore vnknowne to vs when wee ≈øhall dye, to the end that all the dayes of our appoynted time, wee may waite for this day, and all our time looke for this la≈øt time, and prepare our ≈øelues for it. Argus (as is fained) had his head inuironed with an hundred watching eies, ≈øignifiing thus much vnto vs, that he was euery way indued with great wi≈øedome, prouidence, and ≈øingular di≈øcretion. Therefore if a pagan and Heathen man ≈øo excelled in wi≈øedome and prouidence, how much rather ought a Chri≈øtian man to be well furni≈øhed with wi≈øedome & circum≈øpection for his latter end. Be thou therfore an other Argus, nay more wary then he, more wi≈øe and prouident then he, more watchfull & circum≈øpect then hee that thou may≈øt learne to know, to vnder≈øtand, and finally to prouide for thy la≈øt end.

Gregory vpon the watches mentioned by our Sauiour Chri≈øt in the Go≈øpell of Marke in the≈øe words; Mark. 13.35.36.37. Watch yee therefore, for yee know not when the Ma≈øter of the hou≈øe commeth, at euen, or at midnight, or at the cock-crowing, or in the morning, le≈øt comming ≈øuddenly he finde you ≈øleeping; and what I ≈øay vnto you, I ≈øay vnto all, watch; he ≈øaith that there be foure watches in a mans whole life, wherein it behoueth him to be vigilant and carefull, and as a wakefull and warie watchman, to keepe his watch, and ≈øo prepare him≈øelfe for his end.

The fir≈øt is childhood, the ≈øecond youth, the third manhood, the fourth old age. In all which ages he mu≈øt prepare him≈øelfe for death; but he which remi≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ly pa≈ø≈øeth ouer his childhood without this preparation and watchfulne≈ø≈øe, let him be more carefull of his watch in his youth, and pray as it is in Ieremie, Ier. 3.4. My father, be thou the guide of my youth. If he hath pa≈ø≈øed his youth di≈ø≈øolutely, let him be more carefull of his watch in his manhood. And if hee hath pa≈ø≈øed ouer his manhood carele≈ø≈øely, let him in any ca≈øe looke to his la≈øt watch of his old age. Nay, if we prepare not for death before we come to this la≈øt watch of old age (to which verie few doe attaine) it is ≈øo fraile, weake and feeble, and decayed by the cu≈øtome of ≈øinne, that it is an age not ≈øo fit for this preparation and watchfulne≈ø≈øe. For at ≈øuch an age men for the mo≈øt part are like to the Idols of the Heathen, P≈øal. 115.4.5.6.7. which haue mouthes, but ≈øpeake not, eyes, but ≈øee not, eares, but heare not, &c.
Therefore put not off this preparation and watchfulne≈ø≈øe to thy old age, which is thy dotage, but be thou watchfull and prepared in thy childhood‚ñ™ youth, manhood.

Eccl. 12.1. Remember now thy Creator (≈øaith the Preacher) in the daies of thy youth, while the euill dayes come not, nor the yeares draw nigh, when thou ≈øhalt ≈øay I haue no plea≈øure in them. Wherfore not without cau≈øe our Sauiour Chri≈øt crieth ≈øo often in the Go≈øpell. Matth. 24.42. Mar. 13.32.33. Take yee heed, watch and pray, becau≈øe yee know not the day nor the houre, nor when the time is, the which is as much
as if he had more plainely ≈øaid, becau≈øe yee know not that yeere, watch every yeere; becau≈øe yee know not that moneth, watch euery moneth; becau≈øe yee know not that day, watch euery day; and becau≈øe yee know not that houre, watch euery houre. That is to ≈øay, watch continually, yeares, moneths, dayes, houres, yea all your life, if you haue a care of euerla≈øting life. And let your loynes (≈øaith our Sauiour Chri≈øt) be girded about, and your lights burning, Luke 12 35.36.37.38. and yee your ≈øelues like vnto men that waite for their Lord, when he will returne from the wedding; that when he commeth and knocketh, they may open to him immediately. Ble≈ø≈øed are tho≈øe ≈øeruants, whom the Lord when he commeth, ≈øhall finde watching. Verily I ≈øay vnto you, that hee ≈øhall girde him≈øelfe, and make them to ≈øit downe to meate, and will come forth and ≈øerue them. And if he ≈øhall come in the ≈øecond watch, or in the third, and finde them ≈øo, ble≈ø≈øed are tho≈øe ≈øeruants. Prou. 19.20. Therefore heare my coun≈øell and receiue instruction, that thou maye≈øt be wi≈øe in thy latter end.

div.head: THE FOVRTH DIVISION, OF THE RIGHT BEHAVIOVR IN DEATH.
div.p: THis behauiour is nothing el≈øe, but a religious and holy behauiour, e≈øpecially toward God, when we are in or neere the agonie and pangs of death. Which behauiour containes foure e≈øpeciall duties.

The fir≈øt is to die in, or by faith. And to die by faith, is, when a man in the time of death, doth with all his heart wholly rely him≈øelfe on Gods e≈øpeciall loue, fauour & mercie in Chri≈øt, as it is reuealed in his holy word.
