chiefe Butler) be thou forgetfull of thy promi≈øes, Gen. 40.23. nor in≈øult in thy ≈øelfe that thou ha≈øt e≈øcaped death, but call thy ≈øinnes and faults to remembrance with the ≈øame chiefe Butler, Gen. 41.9. and remember rather, that God ≈øeeing how vnprepared thou wa≈øt, hath of his infinit mercy ≈øpared thee, and giuen thee ≈øome little longer time and ≈øpace of breathing and re≈øpite, that thou maye≈øt performe thy vowes and promi≈øes in the amendement of thy ≈øinfull life, and in putting thy ≈øelfe in a better readines again≈øt another time, (and how ≈øoone thou knowe≈øt not:) for though thou ha≈øt e≈øcaped this dangerous ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, (which many others haue not) and then can≈øt ≈øay with the Prophet, The Lord hath cha≈øtened me ≈øore, P≈øal. 118.18. but he hath not giuen me ouer vnto death, yet it may be that thou ≈øhalt not e≈øcape the next. It may bee when a ≈øhip is come to the mouth of the hauen, a bl ‚Ä¢ ≈øt driueth it backe againe, but there it will arriue at the la≈øt, ≈øo mu≈øt thou at length at the gates of death, though thou ha≈øt e≈øcaped this.

Too too many there are that when God vi≈øits them with ≈øharpe di≈øea≈øes, that wakens vp their con≈øciences, and then ≈øicke, ≈øicke, and then if God will repriue them vntill a longer day, oh what Chri≈øtians cour≈øes they vow to take, God proues them they mend in bodies, yeeres: in manners? no, no more then Pharaoh after the plagues remoueall: for many in their afflictions and ≈øickne≈ø≈øes looking for death, how liberall are they in their promi≈øes? but afterward how ba≈øely niggardly are they in their performances? they play childrens play with God, they take away a thing a≈ø≈øoone as they haue giuen it. When Nebuchadnezzar be≈øieged Ieru≈øalem, then the Iewes made a ≈øolemne couenant with the Lord to ≈øet free their ≈øeruants: but no ≈øooner had the king remooued his ≈øiege, but they retracted and repealed their vow, and brought backe againe their ≈øeruants into their former bondage, Ierem. 34.10. So fareth it with the≈øe kind of men, when God layeth fiege to them by ≈øickne≈ø≈øes or ≈øome other pinching affliction, then couenants and promi≈øes are made concerning the putting away of their ≈øinnes, but no
≈øooner doth God begin to depart and ≈ølacke his wrath, but we returne with the dog to the vomit, and with the ≈øo we to the wallowing in the mire, like Pharaoh that di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the I≈øraelites when death entred within his palaces; but pre≈øently after in all ha≈øt makes after them to fetch them back againe.

Con≈øider therefore how fearefull a reckoning thou had≈øt made before Gods iudgment ≈øeat ere this time, if thou had≈øt died of this ≈øicknes, and ≈øpend the time remaining in ≈øuch plea≈øing ≈øort to thy gracious God, that thou maye≈øt be able to make a more cheerefull and ioyfull account of thy life when it mu≈øt expire indeed. Therefore put not farre off the day of thy death, though the Lord for thy good (if thou v≈øe it well) hath put it off; for thou knowe≈øt not for all this how neere it is at hand, and ≈øee that thou (being ≈øo fairely warned) be wi≈øer again≈øt the next time. For if thou bee taken vnprouided againe, thy excu≈øe ≈øhall bee the le≈ø≈øe, and thy iudgement the greater. Thy worke is great which thou ha≈øt to doe, and thy time can be but ≈øhort, and hee who will recompence euery man according to his worke, ≈øtandeth at the doore. Thinke how much worke is behind, and how ≈ølowly thou ha≈øt wrought in the time pa≈øt. The vncleane ≈øpirit is ca≈øt out, Mat. 12.43. let him not enter and come in againe with ≈øeuen wor≈øe then him≈øelfe. Thou ha≈øt ≈øighed out the grones of contrition, thou ha≈øt wept the teares of repentance, thou art wa≈øhed in the poole of Bethe≈øda ≈øtreaming with fiue bloudie wounds, Ioh. 5.4: not with a troubling Angel, but with the Angel of Gods pre≈øence, troubled with the wrath due for thy ≈øinnes; who de≈øcended into hell according to our Creed, that is, the extreame humiliation and aba≈øement of Chri≈øt in his manhood, vnder the power of death and of the graue, beeing kept there as a pri≈øoner in bonds vntill the third day, to re≈øtore thee to ≈øauing health and heauen. Now therefore returne not (with the dog) to thy vomit, nor like the wa≈øhed Sow to wallow in the mire againe, 2. Pet. 2.22. and the filthy puddle of thy former ≈øinnes; left being intangled and ouercome againe with the filthine≈ø≈øe of ≈øinne, (which now thou
ha≈øt e≈øcaped) thy latter end proue much wor≈øe vnto thee then thy fir≈øt beginning.

Twice therefore doth our Sauiour Chri≈øt giue the ≈øame cautionarie warning to healed ≈øinners: Ioh. 5.5.14. The fir≈øt to the man cured of his eight and thirtie yeeres di≈øea≈øe: the ≈øecond to the woman taken in adultery, goe and ≈øinne no more: Ioh. 8.11. hereby teaching vs, how dangerous a relap≈øe and falling againe is into our wonted and accu≈øtomed ≈øinnes. And for this pre≈øent mercy and health, Luke 17.15. imitate the thankefull Leper in the Go≈øpel, and from hence forward tarie thou the Lords lei≈øure, becau≈øe the Lord tarieth thine; he tarieth for thee, till thou change thy euill life, tarie thou for him therefore vntill hee crowne thy good life; and remember the≈øe two things to thy dying day, and thou ≈øha ‚Ä¢ t neuer doe ami≈ø≈øe: Fir≈øt, that there is about thee an all ≈øeeing eye, and an all-hearing eate. He that planted the eare (≈øaith the P≈øalmi≈øt) ≈øhall he not heare? P≈øal. 94.9. he that formed the eye ≈øhall he not ≈øee? goe≈øt thou out? he ≈øeeth thee, returne≈øt thou home? hee ≈øeeth thee: P≈øa. 139.11.12. doth the candle burne? he ≈øeeth thee, is the candle put out? hee ≈øeeth thee: be it light or darkene≈ø≈øe, hee ≈øeeth thee: hee ≈øeeth how thou doe≈øt conuer≈øe with thine owne heart, and how with other men. Therefore in this ca≈øe the coun≈øell of the Philo≈øopher is good: Sic viue cum hominibus qua≈øi Deus audiat, ≈øic loquere cum Deo qua≈øi homines videant: So conuer≈øe with men as if God heard thee, ≈øo conferre with God, as if men ≈øaw thee.

But ≈øuppo≈øe that thou de≈øire≈øt to recouer, and yet neither thy ≈øelfe ≈øees any likelihood, nor God ≈øees it good that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt recouer; then if thou ha≈øt inured thy ≈øelfe to repentance heretofore, and to prayer, it will be the more familiar with thee now at this time. Feruent prayer, P≈øal. 6.6. heartie repentance, and watering thy couch with teares are mo≈øt of all nece≈ø≈øary at this time, that the feare of death may not affright thee, but be a welcome gue≈øt vnto thee. For that being truly penitent at thy departure, thou maye≈øt bee ≈øure with Simeon to depart in peace. Luk. 2.29. And ≈øo God granting not
thy will, but his will, may indeed grant both thy will and his will; thy will, which is not ≈øimply to recouer, but if God will; and his will, which is not to haue thee lye lingering and langui≈øhing any longer in this ≈øhort pilgrimage and warfare, but to triumph for euer in heauen.

Therefore when the pangs of death doe come vpon thee, and the wormes of the earth doe waite for thee: it God giueth thee then thine vnder≈øtanding, ≈øay thou then inwardly to thy ≈øelfe, to thy ≈øicke ≈øoule, Now my pilgrimage is ended, my harue≈øt is inned, my iourney is fini≈øhed, my race is run, my houre-gla≈ø≈øe ≈øpent, my candle burning in the ≈øocket. Many of the godly are gone before me, and I am now to follow after, 2. Tim. 4.7.8. I haue fought a good fight, I haue fini≈øhed my cour≈øe; I haue kept the faith, hence-forth there is laid vp for me a crowne of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, which the Lord, the righteous Iudge, ≈øhall giue me at that day, and not to me onely, but to all them al≈øo that loue his appearing. And, O Lord, I thanke thee, that I am a Chri≈øtian, that I haue liued in a Chri≈øtian Church, that I ≈øhall die among≈øt a Chri≈øtian people, and that I am going to a Chri≈øtian ≈øocietie.

Exod. 33.14.15.16. And whereas the Lord ≈øaid vnto Mo≈øes, My pre≈øence ≈øhall goe with thee, and I will giue thee rest: let vs at this time pray vnto the Lord as Mo≈øes doth, and ≈øay, If thy pre≈øence goe not with mee at this time, then carry me not vp hence. For wherein ≈øhall it be knowne heere that I haue found grace in thy ≈øight? Is it not in that thou goe≈øt with me?

And if we thus ≈øpend the time of our ≈øickne≈ø≈øe in this ≈øort, the Lord when he calleth for vs by Death, ≈øhall finde vs either reading, or hearing, or meditating, or coun≈øelling, or re≈øi≈øting euill, or doing ≈øome good, or repenting or praying; and then wee may bee ≈øure that God will be our guide euen vnto death, P≈øal. 48.14. and will al≈øo ≈øend vs his Ange ‚Ä¢ s to ≈øtand at our beds-head, Luke 16.22. waiting for vs, to carry our ≈øoules into Abrahams bo≈øome, where we ≈øhall ≈øee God the Father, behold God the Sonne, and looke vpon God the holy Gho≈øt, where we ≈øhall enioy the fellow≈øhip of the Angels, the ≈øocietie and company
of the Saints, and where wee ≈øhall liue eternally, obey God perfectly, and raigne with him triumphantly. And be≈øides all this, if we ≈øpend the time of our health, of our ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and of our death in this ≈øort, we ≈øhall leaue a good name and report behinde vs, Eccle≈ø. 7.1. which is better (≈øaith the Preacher) then pretious oyntment, and is rather to be cho≈øen (≈øaith the Wi≈øeman) then great riches, Prou. 22.1. and it will be like the coates and garments which Dorcas made, Acts 9.36. that will remaine behinde vs after that wee are dead and gone, for the good example and incouragement of all others which are to follow vs.

div.head: THE FIFTH DIVISION, THE COMFORT AT OVR OWNE DEATH.
div.p: THe Preacher ≈øaith, Eccle≈ø. 7.1. That the day of our death, is better then the day of our birth. In which parcel of holy Scripture for our comfort at death, three points are to be con≈øidered. Fir≈øt, what is death that is heere mentioned. Secondly, how it can be truely (that is heere mentioned) ≈øaid, that the day of our death is better then the day of our birth. Thirdly, in what re≈øpect it is better.

For the fir≈øt, Death is a priuation of life, as a puni≈øhment ordained of God, and impo≈øed on man for his ≈øinne. It is a priuation of life, becau≈øe the very nature of death is an ab≈øence or defect of that life, which God vouch≈øafed man by his creation. I adde further, that death is a puni≈øhment, more e≈øpecially to intimate the nature and qualitie of death, and to ≈øhew that it was ordained as the meanes of the execution of Gods iudgement and iu≈øtice.
Furthermore, in euery puni≈øhment there bee three workers, the ordainer of it, the procurer, and the executioner.

The ordainer of this puni≈øhment is God, in the e≈øtate of mans innoceÃÑcy, by a ≈øolemne law then made in the≈øe words. In the day that thou eate≈øt thereof, Gen. 2.17. thou ≈øhalt die the death. The Executioner of this puni≈øhmeÃÑt is al≈øo God him≈øelfe, as him≈øelfe te≈øtifieth in the Prophet E≈øay, in the≈øe words. I make
peace and create euill. And this is materiall or naturall euill, E≈øay 45.7. to the latter of which, Death is to be referred; which is the de≈øtruction and aboli≈øhment of mans nature created.

The procurer of this puni≈øhment is not God, but man him≈øelfe, in that man by ≈øinne and di≈øobedience did put vpon him≈øelfe this puni≈øhment. Therfore the Lord in the Prophet O≈øea ≈øaith, O I≈ørael thou ha≈øt de≈øtroyed thy ≈øelfe, Ho≈øea 13.9. but in me is thy helpe.
Again≈øt this it may be obiected, that man was mortall in the e≈øtate of his innocencie before the fall.

An≈øwere; The frame and compo≈øition of mans body con≈øidered in it ≈øelfe, was mortall, becau≈øe it was made of water and earth, and other elements, which are of them≈øelues alterable and changeable; yet if we re≈øpect the grace and ble≈ø≈øing which God did vouch≈øafe mans bodie in his creation, it was vnchangeable and immortal, and ≈øo by the ≈øame ble≈ø≈øing ≈øhould haue continued, if man had not fallen; and man by his fall, depriuing him≈øelfe of this gift, and the ble≈ø≈øing, became euery way mortall. And hereof it is that the Preacher ≈øaith, Loe this onely haue I found, that God made man vpright, Eccle≈ø. 7.29. but they haue ≈øought out many inuentions. Againe, before the fall, mans bodie was but ≈øubiect to death, and could not then be ≈øaid to be dead, but after the fall, it was then not only ≈øubiect to death, but might al≈øo be ≈øaid to bee dead. And therefore now in this re≈øpect the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith, Rom. 8.10 The body is dead becau≈øe of ≈øinne.

Againe, mans bodie in his innocencie, was like vnto the bodie of Chri≈øt, when he was vpon the earth, that is, onely ≈øubiect vnto death, for he could not be ≈øaid to bee dead, becau≈øe in him there was no ≈øinne; and this was mans ca≈øe in his innocencie before his fall.

Thus it appeares in part what death is. And yet for the better clearing of this point, wee are to con≈øider the difference betweene the death of a man, and a bea≈øt. The death of a bea≈øt is the totall and finall aboli≈øhment of the whole creature; for the body is re≈øolued to the fir≈øt matter, and the
≈øoule ri≈øing froÃÑ the temperature of the body, is but a breath, and vani≈øheth to nothing. But in the death of a man it is otherwi≈øe: For though the bodie for a time be re≈øolued and turned into du≈øt, out of which it came, yet it mu≈øt ri≈øe againe at the la≈øt day, and become immortall; but the ≈øoule ≈øub≈øi≈øteth by it ≈øelfe out of the body, and is immortall. The rea≈øon of which difference is, for that the ≈øoule of man is a ≈øpirit or ≈øpirituall ≈øub≈øtance, whereas the ≈øoule of a bea≈øt is no ≈øub≈øtance, but a naturall vigour or qualitie, and hath no being in it ≈øelfe without the body, on which it wholly dependeth. The ≈øoule of a man contrariwi≈øe, being created of nothing, Gen. 2.7. it is ≈øaid, God breathed into his no≈øtrils the breath of life, and then man became a liuing ≈øoule, and ≈øo as well ≈øub≈øi≈øting forth of it, as in it. But when God made the bea≈øts of the earth, he breathed not ≈øuch matter into them, but their bloud is as their ≈øoule, Leuit. 17.14. and their life; for the life of all fle≈øh is the bloud thereof. P≈øal. 49.20. So that, when bea≈øts die, they peri≈øh, as the P≈øalmi≈øt ≈øaith, and that is their end, and their ≈øpirit goeth downeward to the earth, Eccle≈ø. 3.21. but the ≈øpirit of man goeth vpward, ≈øaith the Preacher.

Saint Ambro≈øe takes occa≈øion by this difference, & from the ≈øhape of mans bodie, to aduerti≈øe our minde what our affections ≈øhould be. It is well ordained (≈øaith he) that man hath onely two feete with birds, and not foure feete with bea≈øts, for by this he may learne to flye aloft with the birds, and not with bea≈øtes encline and decline to the gro≈ø≈øer and earthly things of this world.

Heere then we ≈øee, that ≈øince the fall of man, man is not: only ≈øubiect to death, but al≈øo may be ≈øaid a dead man, becau≈øe he ≈øhall as ≈øurely die, as if he were dead already, whereas notwith≈øtanding he hath a forme and ≈øhew of immortalitie. Other things, ≈øo long as they retaine their forme, ≈øo long they doe remaine; A hou≈øe falleth not all the time that his forme and fa≈øhion la≈øteth; the brute bea≈øt dieth not, except he fir≈øt forgoe his life, which is his forme; but man hath a forme which neuer is di≈ø≈øolued, as namely, a minde
endued with rea≈øon, and yet he liueth now but a very ≈øhort time, in re≈øpect that his bodie, by rea≈øon of ≈øinne and di≈øobedience, is become mortall, whereby man is the procuter of his owne death and puni≈øhment.

Therefore it is a true ≈øaying of Saint Gregory, Man is the worke of God, ≈øinne is the worke of man; let vs therefore di≈øcerne what God hath made, and what man hath done; and neither for the error committed by man, let vs hate man, whom God made, nor for the man that is Gods worke, loue the ≈øinne that man hath committed. And againe here note we mu≈øt hate none in re≈øpect of his creation, but in re≈øpect he peruerteth the v≈øe of his creation, for they beare the Image of God which is louely, but they deface and ≈øcratch it out to their owne damnation; ≈øo that we mu≈øt hate not virum, but vitium, the wickedne≈ø≈øe of the man, and not the wicked as he is man.

The kinds of death, as we haue heard in the fir≈øt Diui≈øion, are three-fold; Naturall, Spirituall, Eternall, but they may be reduced into two only, as the kinds of life are, that is, bodily and ≈øpirituall. Bodily death is nothing el≈øe but the ≈øeparation of the ≈øoule from the body, as bodily life is the coniunction of body and ≈øoule. And this death is called the fir≈øt, becau≈øe in re≈øpect of time it goes before the ≈øecond. Spirituall death is the ≈øeparation of the whole man, both in bodie and ≈øoule, from the gratious and glorious fellow≈øhip of God. Of the≈øe two, the fir≈øt is but an entrance to death, and the ≈øecond is the accompli≈øhment of it: for as the ≈øoule is the life of the bodie, ≈øo God is the life of the ≈øoule, and his Spirit is the ≈øoule of our ≈øoules.

Againe, this ≈øpirituall death hath three di≈øti ‚Ä¢ ct and ≈øeuerall degrees. The fir≈øt is, when it is aliue in re≈øpect of temporall life, and yet it lies dead in ≈øinne. Of this degree the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeakes, when he ≈øaith, 1. Tim. 5.6. Shee that liueth in plea≈øure is dead while ≈øhee liueth, and this is the e≈øtate of all men by nature, who are ≈øaid to be dead in ≈øinne.Ephe≈ø. 2.5.

The ≈øecond degree is in the very end of this life, when
the bodie is laid into the earth, then the ≈øoule de≈øcends into the place of torments, Luk. 16.22.23. as the ≈øoule of the rich man in the Go≈øpell.

The third degree is in the day of Iudgement, when the body and ≈øoule at the re≈øurrection of the la≈øt day meete together againe and ≈øhal goe to the place of the damned, there to bee tormented for euer. And this is called by the name of the ≈øecond death, Mat. 25.41. which doth belong onely to the Reprobate.

Hauing thus found the nature, differences, and kinds of death, it is more then manife≈øt, that that place of the Preacher is to be vnder≈øtood, not of the ≈øpirituall death, but of the bodily death, becau≈øe it is oppo≈øed to the natiuitie and birth of man. The words then mu≈øt carry this ≈øence, The time of bodily death, in which there is a ≈øepara ion of the ≈øoule of man from the body, either naturall or violent (being called a bodily or worldly death) is better to the childe of God, then the time in which one is borne, and brought into the world.

Now followeth the ≈øecond point; and that is, how this can bee true which the Preacher ≈øaith, That the day of ones death is better then the day of birth. I make not this que≈øtion to call the Scriptures into controuer≈øie, which are the truth it ≈øelfe, but I doe it to this end and purpo≈øe, that we might without doubting or wauering bee re≈øolued of the truth of this, which the Preacher heere auoucheth for the comfort of all the children of God at their death. For there may be ≈øundrie rea≈øons brought to the contrary of this, which the Preacher heere auoucheth.
Therefore let vs now handle the que≈øtions, rea≈øons, and obiections, which may be alledged to the contrary; which all may be reduced vnto ≈øixe heads.

The fir≈øt is taken from the opinion of wi≈øe men, who thinke it the be≈øt thing of all neuer to bee borne. And the next, be≈øt to die quickly as ≈øoone as he is borne. For Cicero an Heathen man, and renowned for his eloquence and learning,
complaines that nature hath brought man forth into the world, not as a mother, but as a ≈øtepmother, with a body naked, weake and ≈øickly, and with a minde di≈øtracted with cares, deiected with feares, faint with labours, and addicted to lu≈øts and plea≈øures; And hence grew this coÃÑmon ≈øpeech among≈øt the Gentiles related by Ari≈øtotle, repeated by Cicero and Plutarch, and fathered vpon Sylemus, by all three, That the be≈øt thing in the world was, not to be borne at all, and the next, be≈øt to die ≈øoone≈øt. Now if it be the be≈øt thing in the world not to be borne at all, then it is the wor≈øt thing that can be, to die after a man is once borne. An≈øw. There be two ≈øorts of men, the one that liue and die in their fins; the other, that doe vnfainedly repent, and beleeue in Chri≈øt, the one goates, the other ≈øheepe, the one good, the other euill. Now this ≈øentence and ≈øpeech of tho≈øe Heathen men may be truely applied & auouched to the fir≈øt ≈øort, of whom we may ≈øay, as our Sauiour Chri≈øt ≈øaid of Iudas. Mat. 26.24. It had beene good for that man that he had neuer beene borne. But the ≈øaying applied to the ≈øecond ≈øort, is mo≈øt fal≈øe. For to them that in this life turne to God by true and vnfained repentance, the be≈øt thing of all is to be borne, becau≈øe their birth is a degree of preparation vnto all ioy and happine≈ø≈øe, and the next be≈øt for them is to die quickly, becau≈øe by death they doe enter into the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and fruition of the ≈øame ioy and happine≈ø≈øe; for their birth is an entrance into it, and their death the accompli≈øhment of the ≈øame. Plotinus the Philo≈øopher (as S. I reade of Socrates being but an heathen man, that when Crito per≈øwaded him, that if he would not regard his life for his own ≈øake, yet for his wife, children, kinsfolks and friends ≈øake, which depended on him: he an≈øwered, God will care for my wife and children, who fir≈øt gaue them vnto me, and for my kinsfolks and friends, I ≈øhal find the like vnto them, and farre better in the life to come, neither ≈øhall I long want your companie, for you al≈øo are going thither, and ≈øhall ≈øhortly be in the ≈øame place: and they are not lo≈øt but ≈øent before vs, E≈øay 26.19. neither are they dead, but fallen a≈øleepe, hereafter they ≈øhall awake, ≈øaith S. Againe, another obiection: Oh, but my debt is great, if I die now, how can I be comforted at my death, for after my death my creditors will come and ≈øeize on all that I haue, ≈øo cruell are they, and mercile≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo ≈øhall my poore wife and children be vndone for euer: and therefore I would to God I might liue to be out of debt, and to leaue my wife and children free, though I left them litle or nothing be≈øides. As if he ≈øhould ≈øay, I know your woe and carefull thoughts, bee not di≈øcouraged, nor faint in feare vnder the Cro≈ø≈øe; you haue care in your heart, ca≈øt it vpon mee, and I will di≈øcharge it; what you cannot, I can, and of my will be a≈ø≈øured, I doe care for you. Con≈øider the Rauens (≈øaith our Sauiour Chri≈øt) Luk. 12.24.27.28.29. how they
neither ≈øow nor reape, which haue neither ≈øtore-hou≈øe nor barne, and yet God feedeth them. P≈øal. 147.9. Hee giues to the bea≈øt his food (≈øaith the P≈øalmi≈øt) and to the yong Rauens which crie. P≈øal. 104.27. The≈øe waite all vpon thee, that thou maye≈øt giue them their meat in due ≈øea≈øon. How much more (≈øaith our Sauiour) are yee better then bea≈øts or fowles? Math. 6.26. Con≈øider al≈øo (≈øaith our Sauiour) of the lyllies of the field, how they grow, they neither labour nor ≈øpinne, and yet Salomon him≈øelfe, in all his royalty, was not cloathed like one of the≈øe, &c. What concludeth then our Sauiour there? Surely euen this, your heauenly Father knoweth, that you haue need of all the≈øe things. As if he ≈øhould ≈øay, let this ≈øtay and ≈øtrengthen you, and ≈øatisfie and content you euermore, that God, yea God your heauenly Father knoweth your ca≈øe what you and yours from time to time and euer are in need of. O ≈øtrange and ≈øtrong comfort drawne from Gods mercie, loue and knowledge, how ouerwhelmeth it all, that euer fearefull and di≈øtru≈øtfull man can obiect? Gen. 32.10. I am vnworthy, it is true (for ≈øo wee mu≈øt acknowledge with the Patriarch Iacob) that wee are not worthy of the lea≈øt of all Gods mercies. My debts be great, be it ≈øo that they are ten thou≈øand talents; the Creditors are very cruell and mercile≈ø≈øe, yea ≈øo cruell as that mercile≈ø≈øe Creditor, which our Sauiour Chri≈øt ≈øpeaketh of in the Go≈øpell, Mat. 18.28,29,30. P≈øal. 88.18. my ≈øelfe void of friends, and the like. Be it ≈øo that all thy louers, friends and acquaintance are put farre from thee; as the Prophet Dauid complaineth in the P≈øalme; yea let al thy brethren hate thee, as Io≈øeph was of his brethren; Prou. 19.7. let all thy friends goe farre from thee, and be wanting vnto thee; as it is in the Prouerbs, or what≈øoeuer el≈øe it bee, put it all off with this (≈øaith our ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour) that your heauenly Father knoweth the ≈øame, and de≈øpaire you of helpe, when hee faileth to know, and not before, I charge you, but take it at my hands as a ≈øequele ≈øure; he knoweth, and therefore he will prouide in fit time for all things; and his care ≈øhall doe, what yours neuer can, P≈øal. 10.14. P≈øal. 68.5 both for you and yours, if you commit it vnto him. It is God which calles him≈øelfe the Father of Orphans, and
defender of the Widowes; commmend them therefore to his patronage and defence. Euer in ≈øuch griefes as the≈øe are, we ≈øhould remember the promi≈øe of the Lord, which hee made to Abraham and to his ≈øeed. Gen. 17.7. And I will e≈øtabli≈øh my couenant betweene thee and me, and thy ≈øeed after thee in their generations for an euerla≈øting couenant, to be a God vnto thee, and to thy ≈øeed after thee.

All ≈øoules are mine (≈øaith the Lord) both the ≈øoule of the father and of the ≈øonne are mine. The Prophet of the Lord doth te≈øtifie that hee hath beene yong, and al≈øo old, yet neuer did he ≈øee the righteous for≈øaken, P≈øal. 37.25. or his ≈øeede to beg their bread; not meaning that it was impo≈ø≈øible that the childe of a righteous man ≈øhould go a begging, but that it is a thing very rare, and that he was now foure≈øcore years old, yet did he in all his life neuer ≈øee it; and ≈øo haue many men liued till they haue beene of great yeares, and yet ≈øeldome, or not at all, haue they ≈øeene any ≈øuch thing come to pa≈ø≈øe. And againe he ≈øaith, P≈øal. 112.2. The ≈øeed of the righteous ≈øhall bee mightie vpon earth, the generation of the vpright ≈øhall be ble≈ø≈øed. Therefore feare not at Death, for if he take you away, he will giue ≈øome other good meanes to performe his promi≈øe by. He is your God and their God after you, and will not faile them, for he hath ≈øaid it, I will neuer leaue thee, Heb. 13.5. nor for≈øake thee.

In the very matter we ≈øpeake of, ≈øee the experience by a mo≈øt memorable example, and be comforted with it. The
husband died being one of the ≈øonnes of the Prophets, 2. Kings 4.11. and a man that feared God, he died much in debt, not by rea≈øon of any prodigalitie or vnthriftine≈ø≈øe (as many doe) but by the hand of God, and he left his poore wife and children to the crueltie of the cruell Creditor, who came in fierce manner to take away the childreÃÑ froÃÑ their mother, to an≈øwer the debt by bondage. This was a heauie cro≈ø≈øe to a man fearing God, to liue in debt and dye in debt, e≈øpecially debt being ≈øo dangerous to his poore wife & childreÃÑ: yet this it was, that we may not be di≈øcouraged our ≈øelues, or be ouer headie to cen≈øure too far, 1. Sam. 2.7. if the like befall any one of vs. For the Lord doth make poore, and the Lord maketh rich; he bringeth low, and lifteth vp. Prou. 27.24. And as the Wi≈øe-man ≈øaith, Riches are not for euer. Happily this man wi≈øhed that he might liue till he had paid his debt, as you doe, and with condition of Gods good liking; 1. Tim. 5.8. it was but well, if he did ≈øo. For a man is tyed and bound to prouide for his owne family. But it ≈øo plea≈øed not God, for he died and left the debt vnpaid, and his Creditors will be an≈øwered with the bodies of his poore crying children, which hee left with a very ≈øorrowfull and heauy mother behind him; how now ≈øhal this woful widow and fatherle≈ø≈øe children doe? Now ≈øee if God faile to prouide for that thing, he ≈øaw this poore widow had need of, to relieue her ≈øelfe and her children? He directeth his Prophet to bid her borrow ve≈ø≈øels of her neighbours, and him≈øelfe by his powerfull mercie, and mercifull power, ≈øo encrea≈øed and multiplied that little oyle, which ≈øhee had in a cru≈øe, that it paid her Creditors, and yeelded her further maintenance for her and hers, to her vn≈øpeakable ioy and comfort; you know the ≈øtory. Thus then behold and thinke of it, and write this in the palmes of your hands that you neuer forget it, Deut. 11.12. Abac. 2.2. And write it vpon the doore-po≈øtes of thine hou≈øe, and vpon thy gates; yea write it, and make it plaine vpon tables, that he may run that readeth it. God is not the God of this man alone, or of his wife and children, which hee left behind him, but he is your God and our God yea, Iohn 20.17. hee is a God mo≈øt mercifull to all
tho≈øe that doe wholly rely and depend vpon him.

If you may liue to free things your ≈øelfe, it is to be wi≈øhed, and you may with condition aske it, if it may ≈øtand with the good will and plea≈øure of God; but if it plea≈øe God to haue it otherwi≈øe, then grieue not to depart, le≈øt you appeare to tye God to your prouidence, life and meanes, when you ≈øee by this example what hee can doe when you are gone; and not what he can doe, but what he will doe, Iam. 1.6. if you wauer not but beleeue. God was to this Widow in ≈øtead of her hu≈øband, and farre better, ≈øo ≈øhall he be to your wife. God was to the≈øe children in ≈øtead of their father, and better farre, ≈øo ≈øhall hee bee to yours. God was the Executor and paid this debt, and the ouer≈øeer that all was wel, friends were not wanting to mother or children, but God was a friend in the greate≈øt need, that mo≈øt fully, mercifully, and bountifully performed all, and ≈øuffered not the care of his decea≈øed ≈øeruant to be vncared for, nor vncomforted.

Wherefore, let it not grieue thee to die, but thereby receiue comfort, if God will haue it ≈øo, leaue all to him, and remember his promi≈øes, together with this practi≈øe, committing your wife and children to God, and he will protect and prouide for them. Therefore what is vnpaid by thee, he will pay as ≈øhall be be≈øt, and effect what you cannot thinke of, to giue te≈øtimony of his mercy to you and yours. So God is not tyed to your lea≈øes and liuings, when they ≈øhall de≈øcend vnto you, if he plea≈øe he will v≈øe them, if not, he can well want them, and yet pay all, 1. Sam. 2.8. and ≈øet vp the poore fatherle≈ø≈øe child euen with the rulers of the people, as hee hath done in all ages.

div.p: RIght well ≈øaid Chry≈øo≈øtome of the word of God, Rom. 3.2. Ha≈øt thou the Oracles of God? care not for any other teacher, for there is none ≈øhal teach thee like them. So ≈øay I for comfort in this ca≈øe, as Chry≈øo≈øtom doth for doctrine. Ha≈øt thou the holy Scriptures? care not for other comforters, for none ≈øhall comfort thee as the≈øe doe, nay without the≈øe there is no comfort to be had at all; and as Dauid ≈øaid to Abimelech the Prie≈øt concerning the ≈øword of Goliah, 1. Sam. 21.9. ≈øo let vs ≈øay of the≈øe holy Scriptures, There is none like vnto this, giue it me. For if the≈øe will not ≈øerue, then nothing will ≈øerue. For what≈øoeuer woe wringeth, what≈øoeuer ≈øorrow nippeth, what≈øoeuer cro≈ø≈øe grieueth, and what≈øoeuer lo≈ø≈øe troubleth, there is for them all in the word of God mo≈øt ≈øweet comfort; if it be diligently ≈øought, and truly and carefully applied.

Gen. 27.38. We reade in the booke of Gene≈øis, that prophane E≈øau mourned vpon his father I≈øaac, and cryed out mo≈øt pitifully to him, ≈øaying, Ha≈øt thou but one ble≈ø≈øing my father? Not one, but many and infinite are the con≈øolations of God our heauenly Father; for the ≈øtorehou≈øe of his con≈øolations can neuer be emptied: he hath not dealt with vs niggardly or ≈øparingly,

For euery cro≈ø≈øe and lo≈ø≈øe he hath ≈øeuerall comforts and con≈øolations in the holy Scriptures. 2. Cor. 1.3.4. Ble≈ø≈øed be God (≈øaith the Apo≈øtle) euen the Father of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt the Father of mercies, and God of all comfort, who comforteth vs in all our tribulations, that we may bee able to comfort them, which are in any trouble, by the comfort wherewith we our ≈øelues are comforted of God. No maruell therefore if Chry≈øo≈øtome ≈øaith againe in the true feeling thereof, Euer I exhort, and I will neuer cea≈øe exhorting, that not onely here in the Church of God, you would attend vnto tho≈øe things, which are there ≈øaide and taught, (and to ≈øay as Cornelius ≈øaid vnto Peter, Acts 10.33. Now therefore are we all here pre≈øent before God to heare all things that are commanded thee of God.) But at home al≈øo, that you would daily giue your ≈øelues with the men of Be ‚Ä¢ ea to the ≈øearching and reading of the holy Scriptures. Acts 17.11. Search the Scriptures, (≈øaith our Sauiour Chri≈øt) for in them ye thinke to haue eternall life, and they are they that te≈øtifie of me. Iohn 5.39. If you will not vtterly warre again≈øt all truth and rea≈øon, and euen again≈øt God him≈øelfe, I know you will hearken vnto the≈øe things. Con≈øider (≈øaith the Apo≈øtle) what I ≈øay, 2. Tim. 2.7. and the Lord giue thee vnder≈øtanding in all the≈øe things.

It is ≈øufficient to waigh the≈øe matters with the waights of the Lords Sanctuarie, and not needfull to try them by fetching helpes of humane rea≈øon. Yet to giue them ouer mea≈øure, that will not re≈øt ≈øatisfied with the comforts which the holy Scripture doth affoord, let it bee fir≈øt con≈øidered what humane wit and rea≈øon hath ≈øaid in this ca≈øe.

And touching this matter which now is mooued, I haue read, and you may ≈øee what Heathens by learning and naturall light, haue ≈øaid to them≈øelues and their friends in ≈øuch lo≈ø≈øes; but this did I neuer read, neither ≈øhall you finde, that all their comforts haue counteruailed one promi≈øe out of Gods booke. I confe≈ø≈øe the bookes of heathen Writers doe promi≈øe comfort in this ca≈øe, but (alas) they performe it not:
but are like a brooke that ≈øwels in winter when there is no need of it, and is dry in Summer when the pa≈ø≈øenger fainteth and panteth for heat: no, if we will haue good gold, we mu≈øt goe to Ophir: if good balme, to Gilead: if good wine, to Chri≈øt at the wedding of Cana: and if good tidings, to the booke of God. They did ≈øay well in many things, but neuer like this word that is from the Lord. Iohn 7.46. For neuer man ≈øpake like this man, as the officers told the chiefe Prie≈øtes and Phari≈øies concerning Chri≈øt. They con≈øidered the nece≈ø≈øitie of death, the mi≈øeries of life, the examples of great men that had gone before them, and ≈øuch like. But what are the≈øe to tho≈øe that the word of God will ≈øhew vs; our ≈øafety in Chri≈øt, our re≈øurrection in immortality in the pre≈øence of the Father, the Sonne, and the holy Gho≈øt, with ≈øuch like, yet both good vnto a ≈øanctified mind.

Fir≈øt the nece≈ø≈øitie of death is a true comfort again≈øt death, be it of our ≈øelues, or of our friends; no liuing fle≈øh but mu≈øt die, as we haue heard in the fir≈øt Diui≈øion. What man is hee (≈øaith the P≈øalmi≈øt) that liueth and ≈øhall not ≈øee death? P≈øal. 89.48. And ≈øhall we feare that in our ≈øelues, or bewaile immoderatly that in our friends, which cannot be auoided? This were with witle≈ø≈øe wil to di≈øturbe the peace of our whole life, and with a ≈øeruile dread of the la≈øt houre, to bereaue of comfort all the re≈øt of our houres that we are to liue in this pre≈øent euill world, which in your iudgment conceiue how fond a thing it were.

The carefull view of natures cour≈øe, doth ≈øhew vs degrees from age to age till we come to a full, and a like decrea≈øe by ≈øtep after ≈øtep, till we come to the change againe. Youth followeth childhood, and age followeth youth by a≈ø≈øured nece≈ø≈øitie, if we liue. But when we are children, wee feare not to be men, neither when we are men, to become olde; but many rather wi≈øh it, why then ≈øhould we either feare in our ≈øelues, or lament in our friends, death to follow age in his cour≈øe appointed, more then age to follow youth, as was ≈øaid before? Surely the one mu≈øt bee receiued as well as the
other without choice. And whereas Chri≈øt ≈øaid in the Go≈øpel touching man and wife, Matth. 19.9. But if I tie God to them, and thinke all is gone when they are gone, where is my hope? what plea≈øure to God, ≈øo to tru≈øt in him, that I tru≈øt more in my friends, and cry out when they goe? how ≈øhall I doe? how ≈øhall I liue? what ioy can I now haue? Is this hope? is this tru≈øt? is this faith? fie, that euer affections and pa≈ø≈øions ≈øhould carie any good child of God ≈øo far from his dutie, and from true knowledge. I ≈øay againe, our friends are our comfort, while the Lord lendeth them, and when our friend returneth to his earth, yet the Lord is in heauen, where he euer was, (if I haue lo≈øt my father) to be my father, mother, ≈øi≈øter, friend, yea all in all to me, what≈øoeuer I want. Therefore while he liueth, which is and ≈øhall bee for euer, I cannot be friendle≈ø≈øe, though my friends die or depart from me, but that either for one, he will rai≈øe me vp another, or him≈øelfe ≈øupplie the place which is be≈øt of all. Mourne not then I pray you as one without hope, but hearken vnto the Apo≈øtle, and ≈øhew foorth your faith, hope, and obedience vnto God, to the glorie of God and your owne prai≈øe.

Againe, wee read in the booke of Leuiticus, Leuit. 10.3. that the ≈øonnes of Aaron, Nadab and Abihu were ≈ølaine by the Lord in his anger, for their ≈øinnefull pre≈øumption in offering vp ≈øtrange fire, which the Lord commanded them not, which was a fearefull ≈øight and ≈øpectacle to the fathers eyes, to ≈øee two ≈øonnes at once, and in ≈øuch ≈øort dead. Yet what did Aaron; I pray you marke the text, I will ≈øaith the Lord bee ≈øanctified in them that come nigh me, and before all the people I will be glorified. And Aaron (≈øaith the holy Gho≈øt there) held
his peace. And what an example is this, if any thing may mooue you to ≈øtay your affections for the death of your friends. Againe, it is ≈øaid in the booke of the Reuelation, And I heard a voyce from heauen, Reu. 14.13. ≈øaying vnto me, Write, Ble≈ø≈øed are the dead which die in the Lord from henceforth, yea (≈øaith the Spirit) that they may re≈øt from their labours, and their workes follow them. Your friend is dead in the Lord, and therefore ble≈ø≈øed: will you then weepe and lament for him? his workes follow him, and the Lord in mercie hath crowned his obedience, according to his promi≈øe, and will you looke awry at it? God forbid. Againe, con≈øider with your ≈øelfe that your friends walk with God, and are gone to their heauenly Father in peace, they are gathered vnto their people, they are not dead, but ≈øleepe, and their fle≈øh re≈øteth in hope, they are gone the way of all fle≈øh, and doe now behold the face of God in heauen, and what cau≈øe of ≈øorrow is this to any friend that loueth them? If your friend were di≈øcharged and relea≈øed out of pri≈øon and mi≈øerie, and preferred to the palace of an earthly prince, and to his Court, to his great and exceeding ioy and content, would you ≈øhewe your loue and contentment toward him in bewailing the ≈øame? how much le≈ø≈øe then ≈øhould you lament his preferment into Gods euerla≈øting Court and kingdome, to his vn≈øpeakable ioy and comfort?
Thus may you gather many places of holy Scripture, and on this ≈øort meditate on them. For ≈øweet is the word of God again≈øt all ≈øorrowes and griefes, and by name again≈øt this.
But it may happily be obiected, it is your child that is dead, and it died before it could well be baptized, this grieueth me more then otherwi≈øe it would, and ≈øo you feare your childs e≈øtate.

An≈øw. God forbid that we ≈øhould either ≈øpeake or think ≈øo, ≈øeeing the Lord neuer ≈øaid ≈øo, but contrariwi≈øe the Scripture witne≈ø≈øeth, that they are in the Couenant of God, and ≈øo in ≈øtate of ≈øaluation ≈øo ≈øoone as they are borne: and Bapti≈øme doth not make them Chri≈øtians that were none before,
but is the Sacrament, the ≈øeale, the ≈øigne, the badge of them that are Chri≈øtians before. Be≈øides it is not the want of the Sacrament, that depriueth a man of Gods fauour: for the children of the I≈øraelites were not circumci≈øed all tho≈øe fortie yeeres which they liued in the wilderne≈ø≈øe: the rea≈øon whereof was, becau≈øe they were euer to remoue and iourney when≈øoeuer the pillar of the cloud that was their guide, a≈øcended and went forward, Numb. 9.18, &c. ≈øo that they were alwaies to attend vpon the cloude both night and day, not knowing when it would remooue; and therefore could not circumci≈øe their children in the wilderne≈ø≈øe, as yee may read, Io≈øh. 5.2, &c. but it is the contemning or de≈øpi≈øing of the Sacrament, that depriueth men of Gods fauour when they make no more account of it, then E≈øau did of his birth-right, Gen. 25.32. then Ahaz did of the Lords helpe, E≈øay 7. and it is al≈øo the neglecting of it, when God offereth time and opportunitie that we might haue it. Againe, the Lord neuer ≈øaid, that who≈øoeuer died vncircumci≈øed or vnbaptized ≈øhould be wiped out of the booke of life, but hee hath ≈øaid, Gen. 17.12.14‚ñ™ that who≈øoeuer contemneth, or carele≈øly neglecteth the Sacraments, ≈øhal be cut off from among his people. And ≈øo read you the notes vpon that ≈øeuenteenth chapter of Gene≈øis, and I hope they ≈øhall content you for this matter. God is not tyed to the Sacrament, nor euer was. The contempt hurteth, but not the want, when it is again≈øt your will.

Obiect. Happily your child was of ripe yeeres, and withall ≈øo toward, that it could not be, but that he ≈øhould come to ≈øome great place and preferment if he had liued, both for the good of him≈øelf and his friends; and that he in his youth and the flower of his age, ≈øhould thus bee taken away, is a great lo≈ø≈øe ≈øay you.

An≈øwer. True it is, that the lo≈ø≈øe is great in re≈øpect of the world, but what is that if we con≈øider God; God is al≈øo able to ≈øupplie all that, ≈øome other way, if we take it well. This is apparant, that what good or preferment could haue come
to him any way or to his friends, if he had liued, the Lord for ≈øome purpo≈øe as yet happily hidden, hath preuented: but yet his arme is not ≈øhortened, as I ≈øaid, to doe vs good ≈øome other way, but it might perhaps prooue otherwi≈øe contrarie to our expectation, if he had liued longer, and then it would haue beene a great griefe vnto vs. But admit that it would haue beene as you hope if he had liued longer, yet he is more highly preferred euen to the highe≈øt heauens, and to the pre≈øence of God, and this no earthly preferment can match. And except we be wholy earthly our ≈øelues, we cannot but ≈øauour this, and not let his youth grieue vs, for no youth nor age is too good for God, when he is plea≈øed to take them.

A foole or a child ≈øeeing a goodly clu≈øter of grapes, thinketh it pitie to put them into the pre≈ø≈øe to deface them, but he that is wi≈øe knoweth that thereby the liquour which is in them is pre≈øerued, and that this timely gathering is a meanes to keepe them from corruption. So we thinke ≈øometime, Oh, it is great pitie ≈øuch a one ≈øhould die ≈øo ≈øoone, ≈øo towardly a youth, ≈øo good a creature can hardly be ≈øpared; but God in his wi≈øedome knoweth it to be good. And if he cut off the life of that good and godly king Io≈øiah, as it were in the middle of the ≈øtemme, 2. Kings 22.20. doubtle≈ø≈øe it is for this cau≈øe, that his eies may not ≈øee the manifold euils to come. If you will be ruled to weigh things with rea≈øon, you may well ≈øee mercie euen in this timely death; for many are the perils both of bodie and ≈øoule, that young men auoid when they are taken hence, fal≈øe doctrine, here≈øies, errours, and many grieuous ≈øinnes, wounding the very con≈øcience with a biting worme that euer gnaweth; publike calamities, and ruine of ≈øtate, many priuate mi≈øeries great and grieuous, which no man can thinke of beforehand, more bitter to good men then any death: from all which this happie deliuerance in time of youth doth free your child, and ≈øet him ≈øafe, that you ≈øhall neuer mourne with him, nor for him that way. And herein we haue Dauid an example of godly fortitude, who hauing a child ≈øicke, did while it liued afflict his ≈øoule, be≈øought
God for the child, and fa≈øted and wen ‚Ä¢
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and lay all night vpon the earth, and would not be comforted. Thus while there was hope of remedie, he gaue way to the ≈øorrow of his heart, 2. Sam. 12.16. but when Dauid perceiued that the child was dead, then he aro≈øe from the earth, and wa≈øhed and anointed him≈øelfe, and changed his apparell, and came into the hou≈øe of the Lord, and wor≈øhipped, and after came to his owne hou≈øe, and bad that they ≈øhould ≈øet bread before him and he did eate. His ≈øorrow ended, when he once ≈øaw there was no hope of enioying any longer the companie of his child. Now this cour≈øe ≈øeemed vnto his ≈øeruants a new and ≈øtrange kind of Philo≈øophie, that he ≈øhold mourn in the danger of death, and yet reioice, or at lea≈øt comfort him≈øelfe with any content in death. And therefore his ≈øeruants ≈øaid vnto him, What thing is this that thou ha≈øt done, 2. Sam. 12.21, thou didde≈øt fa≈øt and weepe for the child while it was aliue, but now he is dead thou doe≈øt ari≈øe and eate meat. And what rea≈øon had hee for this ≈øtrange and vnwonted behauiour? He ≈øaid, While the child was aliue I fa≈øted and wept, for I ≈øayd, Who can tell whether God will haue mercie on me, that the child may liue, but now being dead, wherefore ≈øhall I fa≈øt? Can I bring him againe any more. I ≈øhall goe to him, but hee ≈øhall not returne to mee any more. Behold the ≈øame thing that maketh thee to mourne, namely, that thy dead ≈øhall not returne to thee, the very ≈øame con≈øideration Dauid made the ground of his quiet and content. And thereupon he comforted his heart, and would not continue in heauin≈ø≈øe for that which could not bee helped. So that it is to a right vnder≈øtanding man, ground inough to build content and quietne≈ø≈øe of heart vpon, that God hath done his worke which thy ≈øorrow cannot reuoke. But peraduenture it will be here obiected, that afterward when Dauid heard of his ≈øonne Ab≈øolons death, hee did ≈øo greatly lament and bewaile the ≈øame, that hee would in no ≈øort bee comforted quite contrarie to that which before hee practized; for it is ≈øaid that he was much mooued, 2. Sam. 18.33. and went vp to the chamber ouer the gate, and wept as he went ≈øaying. O my ≈øonne
Ab≈øolon, my ≈øonne, my ≈øonne Ab≈øolon, would God I had died for thee. O Ab≈øolon my ≈øonne, my ≈øonne.

For the an≈øwering of this obiection, and your better ≈øatisfaction herein, wee are to vnder≈øtand that Dauid knew that he had a wicked and rebellious ≈øonne, of the e≈øtate of who≈øe ≈øaluation he had great cau≈øe to doubt, becau≈øe he died in rebellion, which indeed may ≈øeeme to bee the principall cau≈øe of his exceeding ≈øorrow and lamentation, and not ≈øo much for the death of his ≈øonne, as for that cau≈øe. But of his childe he beleeued that he died in the ≈øtate of grace, and ≈øo was made partaker of ≈øaluation, which was the cau≈øe that he was comforted pre≈øently after his death, ≈øaying, that his ≈øon ≈øhould not returne, but that he him≈øelfe ≈øhould goe to him. Euen ≈øo in like manner, if we feare the e≈øtate of our childe or friend that is dead, then indeed haue wee great cau≈øe to weepe, mourne and lament for him, as Dauid did heere for Ab≈øolon: but if we haue no ≈øuch feare, and do hope well and the be≈øt of the e≈øtate of our childe or friend; then mu≈øt wee with Dauid comfort our ≈øelues, and ≈øay, But now he is dead, wherefore ≈øhould I fa≈øt and weepe? can I bring him back againe, I ≈øhall goe to him, but he ≈øhall not returne to me.

Let them mourne for their dead, that know not the hope of the dead, and ≈øuppo≈øe them extinct that are departed. But let them that in the Schoole of Chri≈øt haue learned what is the condition & hope of the dead‚ñ™ how their ≈øoules doe pre≈øently liue with Chri≈øt, and that their bodies ≈øhall be rai≈øed vp in glorie at the la≈øt day, let them reioyce on the behalfe of their dead, Amos 8.10. and throw off that burden of ≈øorrow, which is ≈øo heauie vnto them. But you will ≈øay he was my onely childe, and therefore his death mu≈øt needs be grieuous. Zach. 12.10. Indeed the death of an onely childe is very great and grieuous to parents, and a cau≈øe of great heauine≈ø≈øe and lamentation: yet remember that Abraham was readie to haue ≈øacrificed his only ≈øonne I≈øaak, Gen. 22.3.10. the promi≈øed ≈øeede, at Gods commandement. Iohn 3.26. And God gaue his only Sonne Chri≈øt Ie≈øus to death for our ≈øaluation. And to comfort you to the full, as Elkanah
≈øaid to Anna, ≈øo al≈øo much more may the Lord ≈øay to vs, 1. Sam. 1.18. Am not I better to you then ten ≈øonnes? Then though hee bee your only childe, and all that you haue, there is no iu≈øt cau≈øe of complaint and griefe, ≈øeeing the Lord hath taken but his owne, and al≈øo ≈øeeing in his taking of him, you giue him but as your pledge and earne≈øt, to binde vnto you the right of that inheritance, that you expect, or as your feoffee in tru≈øt gone before to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and keepe a place for you in heauen.

Tru≈øt me now, or el≈øe the time will come when you ≈øhall tru≈øt me, that you haue cau≈øe, and cau≈øe againe to lament and mourne, not for them, who dying in the Lord, are happie with the Lord, and re≈øt from all their labours and mi≈øeries, but as Chri≈øt ≈øaid in the Go≈øpell to the woman that followed him, Weepe not for me, but weepe for your ≈øelues and your children: Luke 23.28. ≈øo we for our ≈øelues and our children; for hauing been ≈øafe by them, and ≈øtrengthned through them, they are taken away from the plague, wee lye open to it, and it commeth the fa≈øter, becau≈øe they which kept it from vs, are remoued. And the greater our lo≈ø≈øe is, the greater is their gaine, and the more cau≈øe haue we to ≈øorrow for our ≈øelues, although to reioyce on their behalfe, and to lament for our ≈øinnes, that haue depriued vs of their graces, goodne≈ø≈øe, prayers and holy company; and let vs follow them in their faith, vertue, pietie, godline≈ø≈øe and good workes.

And yet, if for all this, their lo≈ø≈øe, & the want of their pre≈øence be grieuous vnto you, and that you ≈øtill de≈øire their pre≈øence, and would ≈øee them: let me ≈øpeake to you, as Chry≈øo≈øtome did to ≈øome that were ≈øo affected. Doe you de≈øire to ≈øee them? then liue a like vnto them, and ≈øo you ≈øhall ≈øoone enioy their holy and comfortable pre≈øence, but if you refu≈øe ≈øo to doe, neuer looke to enioy or ≈øee them againe.

It is written of Ierome, that when he had read the life and death of Hillarion, and ≈øaw that after he had liued religiou≈øly, he died mo≈øt comfortably and happily, ≈øaid, Well, Hillarion ≈øhall be the champion whom I will imitate: euen ≈øo let
vs ≈øay with Ierome, Well, this godly friend of ours, which is decea≈øed, ≈øhall be our champion, whom we will imitate, we will follow his cha≈øtitie, iu≈øtice, pietie and godline≈ø≈øe. And ≈øo, if you endeauour and doe, ≈øay and performe, you ≈øhall be ≈øure to enioy that in future time, which hee po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth in the pre≈øent, that is, heauenly and eternall bli≈ø≈øe and happine≈ø≈øe.

What Pilgrime doth not make ≈øpeed to returne home into his owne countrie? Who ha≈øting to ≈øaile homewards, doth not wi≈øh for a pro≈øperous winde, that he may ≈øpeedily embrace his long de≈øired friends and parents? and what are we but pilgrimes on earth: what is our country, but Paradi≈øe, who are our parents, but the Patriarkes? Why make we not ha≈øt to runne vnto them, that we may ≈øee our countrie, ≈øalute our parents? an infinite number of acquaintance expect vs there; our parents, brethren, ≈øi≈øters, friends, children, kindred, that are alreadie ≈øecure of their owne immortalitie, but yet ≈øollicitous for our ≈øafetie, what ioy will it bee to ≈øee, to embrace them?

Conclude then with your heart, that you will bee ≈øtrong again≈øt ≈øuch lo≈ø≈øes, and pray to the giuer of ≈øtrength that you may be ≈øtrong, and leaue your lo≈ø≈øes to the Lord your God, that hath gained them, ble≈ø≈øed for them, ble≈ø≈øed for you, with many thankes for euer and euer.

div.head: THE SEVENTH DIVISION OF THE CASES WHEREIN IT IS Vnlawfull, and wherein Lawfull to de≈øire DEATH.
div.p: TOuching the ca≈øes wherein it is vnlawful to de≈øire death, they may be reduced principally into three.

The fir≈øt is, if God can bee more honoured by our life, then by our death, then in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, it is altogether vnlawfull to de≈øie death, but rather on the contrary we are to de≈øire and pray for life. For which purpo≈øe wee haue diuers examples in the holy Scriptures to warrant the ≈øame, as of King Dauid, and king Ezechiah. Dauid bewayled him≈øelfe in many of his P≈øalmes, that If God tooke him away, he ≈øhould lacke occa≈øion to honour & pray≈øe him, as he was wont to doe while≈øt he was among≈øt men; and therefore hee de≈øired longer life, that he might ≈øet forth the honour of God among≈øt the people. Returne O Lord (≈øayth he) P≈øal. 6.4.5. deliuer my Soule, O ≈øaue mee for thy mercies ≈øake; for in death there is no remembrance of thee, in the graue who ≈øhall giue thee thank? Againe, P≈øa. 30.8.9.10 I cryed vnto thee O Lord, &c. When I go down into the pitte, ≈øhall the du≈øt prai≈øe thee? &c Againe, P≈øal 88 9 10 11 12. Mine eye mourneth by rea≈øon of affliction, &c. ≈øhall the dead ri≈øe and prai≈øe thee? And againe, P≈øal 118.17. I ≈øhall not dye but liue, and declare the workes of the Lord.

Ezechiah bewayled him≈øelfe, E≈øa. 38.18.19.20. when hee heard the
me≈ø≈øage of death, and praied for longer life, knowing therby that God ≈øhould bee more honoured by his life, then by his death: And therefore ≈øayth hee, The graue cannot pray≈øe thee, &c.

And thus may euery godly Chri≈øtian de≈øire life, and not death, to this end onely that God thereby may be glorified: But yet in this ca≈øe, although it be vnlawfull to de≈øire death, ≈øo long as God may bee glorified by our Life, yet in praying for life to this end, we mu≈øt referre all to Gods good wil and plea≈øure. Therfore if any wil obiect & ≈øay, I might in my place by mine endeauour (≈øuch as it is) for the time to come; further profite the Church of God, and greatly honour him; for this end therefore, I could wi≈øh that the ≈øpace of a longer life might be graunted vnto me.

An≈øwer. As the Lord ≈øayd vnto Dauid, 1 King. 8.18.19. Whereas it was in thine heart to build an hou≈øe to my name, thou did≈øt well that it was in thine heart. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe thou ≈øhalt not build the hou≈øe, but thy ≈øonne which ≈øhall come forth of thy loynes, he ≈øhall build the hou≈øe vnto my name. Euen ≈øo it may bee ≈øayde to thee, that whereas it is in thine heart to glorifie God, and to profite his Church; and therefore thou coulde≈øt wi≈øh, that the ≈øpace of a longer life might be granted vnto thee; to that end thou doe≈øt well that it is in thine heart to doe ≈øo. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, all this mu≈øt bee commended to Gods di≈øpo≈øing, that is, how long God wil haue thee to remaine in health and life for his glorie, and for the good of his Church. For hee that hath furni≈øhed thee with the giftes of teaching or exhortation, or any other good gift for the glory of God and good of his Church, he doth know how to furni≈øh others al≈øo with the ≈øame, when thou art gone; and as God would not let Dauid build his Temple, but did re≈øerue it to be performed afterward by Salomon; ≈øo God for ≈øome ≈øecret cau≈øe, will not haue that good worke furni≈øhed by thee, but re≈øerueth it for ≈øome other time, and ≈øome other per≈øon. Therefore if thou art ≈øtraightned
with the Apo≈øtle, Philip. 1.23. that thou doe≈øt not know which of the≈øe thou ≈øhoulde≈øt chu≈øe, hauing a de≈øire to be di≈ø≈øolued, and to be with Chri≈øt (which is better for thee) or to abide in the fle≈øh, which is more profitable for the church; Know that to dye, is aduantage vnto thee; but to liue, is aduantage to the Church. No man of vs (≈øayeth the Apo≈øtle) Rom. 14.7.8 liueth to him≈øel≈øf, and no man dyeth to him≈øelfe; for whether we liue, wee liue to the Lord, (to the end that wee may glorifie him, and gaine more ≈øoules to him in the Church) or whether we dye, we dye to the Lord, (that we may obey his Fatherly will, calling vs out of our Station.) Whether therefore we liue or dye, we are the Lords, (that mo≈øt mighty, gentle, and mercifull Lord, From who≈øe loue, neyther life nor death can ≈øeparate vs. Rom. 8.38.39.

Thou ha≈øt hitherto obeyed the will of the Lord mo≈øt faithfully, ≈øpending thy ≈øeruices on the Church militant; obey him further mo≈øt readily, embracing his will, that calles thee to the ≈øociety of the Church triumphant.
Thou art rightly carefull out of charity for the encrea≈øe of the church, notwith≈øtanding thou oughte≈øt out of faith to commit the care of gouerning, teaching and con≈øeruing the ≈øame vnto God.

There is nothing heere more whole≈øome, nothing better, nor more conformable to pietie, then for a man to re≈øigne him≈øelfe wholy to the will of God; and to commend the full power of di≈øpo≈øing our life and death to him with godlie prayers. And one of the≈øe two thinges, we may vndoubtedly hope for; that eyther hee will giue vs that which wee aske, or that which hee knoweth to be more profitable; Delight thy ≈øelfe in the Lord (≈øayeth the P≈øalmi≈øt) P≈øal. 37.4.5. and he ≈øhall giue thee the de≈øires of thine heart, commit thy way vnto the Lord, tru≈øt al≈øo in him, and he ≈øhall bring it to pa≈ø≈øe.

And this coniunction and vnion which wee haue in Chri≈øt, is al≈øo ≈øet downe in that heauenly prayer, which our Sauiour Chri≈øt made vnto God his Father, at his la≈øt farewell out of this world immediately before his pa≈ø≈øion and ≈øuffering; Iohn 17. where hee prayeth at large for the accompli≈øhment of this vnion in vs with him. And if our Sauiour-Chri≈øt him≈øelfe did pray vnto his Father for the ful accompli≈øhment of this vnion, that wee might be where he is, for to behold his glorie, then it is lawfull for vs to de≈øire the ≈øame. And this is true loue indeed vnto Chri≈øt our head, to de≈øire to bee with him; for the propertie of true loue is an ardent and burning de≈øire to obtaine that which is beloued. And as a woman that loueth her husband vnfainedly, cannot be content with any loue token ≈øhee receyueth from him in his ab≈øence, but longeth and wi≈øheth, and de≈øireth more and more till ≈øhee receyue him≈øelfe; euen ≈øo, the Soule which is wounded with the loue of Ie≈øus her mercifull husband, hath continuall de≈øire to be with him. I grant euery token ≈øent from him brings comfort, but no contentment till ≈øhe enioy him. If the loue of men compelled the Apo≈øtle to ≈øay to the Corinthians, 2 Cor. 12:14: It is not yours, but you I ≈øeeke. How much more ≈øhould the loue of God compell vs to ≈øay to our Lord Ie≈øus: It is not thy gift but thy ≈øelfe O Lord that I long for; for thou art the portion of my ≈øoule, ≈øeeing I am nothing without thee, let mee ta≈øt the benefit of being thine, I de≈øire thee, & not thine, for thy ≈øelfe, not for thy gifts; I de≈øire thee onely, nothing for thee, P≈øal. 73.25. nothing with thee, nothing be≈øides thee.

The godly Chri≈øtian hath ≈øome liuely foreta≈øt & ≈øweetnes of this ble≈ø≈øed and happy coniunction and vnion with Chri≈øt, and therefore it is a griefe vnto him to be holder from him, and a ioy to remoue vnto him. But certainely
he ≈øhall neuer goe out of this earthly body with ioy, who liues not in this fraile body with grief for his ab≈øence from him. If thou de≈øire≈øt that which thou ha≈øt not (which is heauen) then ≈øhedde thou teares here on earth, that thou maye≈øt obtaine it.

And hereof comes the≈øe and ≈øuch like complaints, As the hart panteth after the water bro ‚Ä¢ kes, ≈øo panteth my ≈øoule after thee O God, my ≈øoule thir≈øteth for God, for the liuing God, when ≈øhall I come and appeare before God?

In this ca≈øe Saint Paul de≈øired death in re≈øpect of him≈øelfe, For to me (≈øayeth he) to liue is Chri≈øt, and to die is gain. But if I liue in my fle≈øh, this is the fruit of my labour; Phil 1.21,22,23. yet what I ≈øhall choo≈øe I wotte not, for I am in a ≈øtraight betweene two, hauing a de≈øire to depart, and to be with Chri≈øt, which is farre better for me. For the Apo≈øtle to haue a de≈øire, is more then ≈øimplie to de≈øire: for it witne≈ø≈øeth two things, fir≈øt, a vehement, ≈øecondly, a perpetuall de≈øire to pa≈ø≈øe to Chri≈øt his head, and this is a ≈øetled de≈øire, which is a gift of Gods grace peculiar onely to the elect of God. In this ca≈øe is al≈øo Simon de≈øired death; for when the holy Gho≈øt reuealed to him, that he ≈øhould not ≈øee death before he had ≈øeen the Lord Chri≈øt, after that hee had ≈øeene him in the Temple, He tooke him vp in his armes, and ble≈ø≈øed God and ≈øayde, Luk. 2,28:29,30. Lord now lette≈øt thou thy ≈øeruant depart in peace, &c. Wherefore hide≈øt thou thy face (≈øaith Augu≈øtine to God) happily thou wilt ≈øay, No man ≈øhall ≈øee mee and liue; Oh then Lord, that I were dead, ≈øo I might ≈øee thee. Oh let mee ≈øee thee that I may dy; euen heere I will not liue; Dye I would, yea I de≈øire to be loo≈øed & to be with Chri≈øt, I refu≈øe to liue, that I may liue with Chri≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ And in this re≈øpect all the godly may de≈øire death. Though he tarrie, Heb. 2,3, Heb. 10.37, Revel. 22.20 wait, for yet a very little while, and he that ≈øhall come will come, and will not tarry. For hee which te≈øtifieth the≈øe thinges, ≈øayth, Surely, I come quickely, Amen, Amen. Euen ≈øo come Lord Ie≈øus.

div.head: THE EIGHTH DIVISION, OF THE GLORIOVS ESTATE OF Gods Children after DEATH.
div.p: TOuching the glorious e≈øtate of the children of God after death, which way ≈øhall I beginne to expre≈ø≈øe the ≈øame, when as the ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle ≈øayeth, Eye hath not ≈øeene, Eare hath not heard, neyther hath it entred into the heart of man, 1 Cor. 2.9, the things which God hath prepared for them that loue him.

I remember what is regi≈øtred of a certaine Painter, who being to expre≈ø≈øe the ≈øorrow of a weeping Father, hauing ≈øpent his skill before in ≈øetting forth of the ≈øayde pa≈ø≈øions of his children, did thinke it be≈øt to pre≈øent him vpon his Table to the beholders view, with his face couered; that ≈øo hee might haue that griefe to bee imagined by them, which he found him≈øelfe vnable to ≈øet out at the full. The like mu≈øt I doe in this ca≈øe, for the glory of that glorious e≈øtate which the children of God ≈øhall hereafter enioy: I mu≈øt commend to you with a kind of ≈øilent admiration, that ≈øo you may with your ≈øilence ≈øuppo≈øe that to be infinite, which you ≈øee that I will not aduenture to expre≈ø≈øe. What hand can mea≈øure the bounds of infinite? What mind can number the years of eternitie? what hand, what mind can mea≈øure, can number the vnmea≈øurable
mea≈øure, & innumerable number of the ioyes of Heauen? O that I had the tongues of the glorious Angels in ≈øome ≈øort for your ≈øakes to vtter, or rather that you had the harts of the glorified Saints, in ≈øome little ≈ømall mea≈øure to conceiue of ≈øome part of this glory. But this glorious Sunne doth ≈øo dazell my weake eyes, this bottomle≈ø≈øe depth ≈øo ouerwhelme my ≈øhallow heart; and the ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing greatne≈ø≈øe of the≈øe ioye? do euery way ≈øo ouercharge me, that I mu≈øt needes ≈øtand a while ≈øilent, amazed, and a≈øtoni≈øhed at the ≈øerious con≈øideration of the exceeding, aboundant excellency of this glory, which requires rather the tongues and pennes of Angelles then of men to de≈øcribe and expre≈ø≈øe the the ≈øame; yea rather it cannot bee perfectly de≈øcribed and expre≈ø≈øed by Angels them≈øelues. And therefore I mu≈øt be content then darkely to ≈øhaddow it out, ≈øith liuely repre≈øentation of it is meerely impo≈ø≈øible. This I may ≈øay in a word, that looke what difference there is in proportion betwixt the cope of heauen, and the earth, which re≈øpectiuely to it is but as a pricke in the midde≈øt of a center, the ≈øame & much more there is betwixt the glorie of all the Kingdoms of the world vnited together (if it were po≈ø≈øible) into one, and that which the Apo≈øtle calleth the glory which ≈øhall bee ≈øhewed hereafter: Better it is with a kinde of ≈øilent a≈øtoni≈øhment to admire it, then to take on vs eyther to di≈øcribe it, or to comprehend it in particular.

Yet giue me leaue to ≈øet before you for the furtherance of your priuate meditations, a little ≈øhadow or glymp≈øe thereof, euen as it were but the backe-parts thereof, which Mo≈øes was permitted to ≈øee; betwixt which and it, notwith≈øtanding, there is as much difference, Exod. 33.23. as betweene one droppe of water, and the maine Ocean ≈øea.

A word fitly ≈øpoken (≈øayth the Wi≈øeman) is like apples of gold, and pictures of ≈øiluer. Prou. 25.11 Wee reade in the booke of Deutronomy, that when Mo≈øes went vp from the playnes of Moab vnto the mountaine of Nebo, Deut. 34.1.2.3.4. to the toppe of Pi≈øgah
that is ouer again≈øt Iericho, that there the Lord ≈øhewed him all the land of Gilead vnto Dan, and all Nepthacy, and all the land of Ephraim and Mana≈ø≈øes, and all the land of Iudah, vnto the vtmo≈øt ≈øea, and the South and the playne of the land of Iericho, the Citie of Palme trees vnto Zoar. And this is the land which I ≈øware (≈øayth the Lord) vnto Abraham‚ñ™ and vnto I≈øaacke, and vnto Iacob ≈øaying, I will giue vnto thy ≈øeed, and I haue cau≈øed thee to ≈øee it with thine eyes, And this was that earthly Canaan, euen that promi≈øed land which is ≈øo much commended in the holy Scriptures. Euen ≈øo, if we will take a little paines to goe vp to the mountaine of the Lorde which the Prophet E≈øay ≈øpeaketh of, E≈øa. 2.2. then there in in ≈øome ≈ømall mea≈øure may we take a ≈øight and view, not of the glory of the earthly Canaan, but of the glory of the heauenly Canaan; and where the Deuill (as it is ≈øayd in the Go≈øpell) tooke Ie≈øus vp into an exceeding high mountaine, Mat. 4.8, and ≈øhewed him all the Kingdomes of the world, and the glory of them. Here vpon this mountaine of the Lord, there is ≈øhewed vnto vs the Kingdome of God, and the glory of the ≈øame; All which, the Lord will giue vs (being the right owner thereof) if we feare, ≈øerue and wor≈øhip him; and wee neede not with Mo≈øes to clime vp to any earthly mountaine, to ≈øee and behold the Kingdom of God, and the glory therof. Deut. 30.12.13.14. It is not in heauen (≈øayth Mo≈øes in another ca≈øe) that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt ≈øay; Who ≈øhall goe vp to heauen for vs, and bring it vnto vs, that wee may heare it, and doe it; neyther is it beyond the ≈øea, that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt ≈øay, Who ≈øhall goe ouer the Sea for vs, and bring it vnto vs, that we may heare it, and doe it? But the word is verie nigh vnto thee, in thy mouth, and in thine heart, and there we may behold this glory. Search the Scriptures (≈øayth our Sauiour Chri≈øt in the Go≈øpell of Saint Iohn) for in them yee thinke to haue eternall life, and they are they which te≈øtifie of mee. Iohn 5.39. And we may adde further al≈øo, that they are they which te≈øtifie of this glorious e≈øtate of the children of God after death; Io≈øeph gaue his brethren
proui≈øion for the way: but the full ≈øackes were kept in ≈øtore vntill they came to their Fathers hou≈øe: God giues vs here a ta≈øte and a≈ø≈øay of his goodne≈ø≈øe; but the maine ≈øea of his bounty and ≈øtore is hoorded vp in the kingdom of heauen.

It is an v≈øuall thing in the Scripture to repre≈øent ≈øpirituall and heauenly things by bodily and earthly things, that therein as in gla≈ø≈øes we may behold heauenly thinges, although ob≈øcurely; which notwith≈øtanding, we cannot otherwi≈øe perceiue, and ≈øee immediatly being too glorious and vehement obiects for our eyes. Therefore as we can not behold the light of the Sunne in the Sunne, but by reflection thereof in the Moone, in the Starres, in the water, or other bright body, or el≈øe by refraction thereof in the mi≈øtie ayre; ≈øo the ≈øoule while it is in the body heareth, ≈øeeth, vnder≈øtandeth, imagineth with the body, and in a bodily manner, and therefore is not capable of ≈øuch hearing, ≈øeeing, vnder≈øtanding‚ñ™ imagining as it ≈øhall bee when it is ≈øeparate from the body; hence it is, that the Apo≈øtle ≈øayth- 1. Cor. 13.12 Wee now ≈øee through a gla≈ø≈øe darkely. Wee conceyue of heauen by a Citty, who≈øe walles, pauements and man≈øions are of gold, pearle, Chri≈øtall, Emeralds, as it is de≈øcribed in the booke of the Reuelation, Reuel. 21.10 which wee ≈øhall afterwards heare more at large.

And to beginne fir≈øt of all with the comfortes and benefites of this life, euen they (although mi≈øerable) doe argue that a far better e≈øtate is re≈øerued for vs in heauen. We ≈øee that God euen here vpon earth notwith≈øtanding our manifold ≈øinnes wherby we dayly offend him, and which may iu≈øtly cau≈øe him (as the Prophet ≈øpeaketh) Ier. 5.25. to withhold good things from vs;) yet he in great mercy vouch≈øafeth vs many plea≈øures, and furni≈øheth vs not onely with matters of nece≈ø≈øity (who dayly, ≈øayeth the P≈øalmi≈øt, P≈øal. 68.19. loadeth vs with benefites) but al≈øo of delights. There is a whole P≈øalme ≈øpent onely in this matter, which is the 104. P≈øalme; P≈øal. 104. a P≈øalme worthy to bee written in letters
of gold, and as Mo≈øes ≈øpeaketh in Deuteronomy, Deut. 11.20. vpon the dore po≈øtes of thine hou≈øe, and vpon the gates, yea vpon the Table of thine heart (as the Wi≈øe-man ≈øpeaketh) Pro. 7.3. for the admirable excellency thereof.

God cau≈øeth (≈øayth Saint Ciprian) the Sunne to ri≈øe and ≈øet in order, the ≈øea≈øons to obey vs, the elements to ≈øerue vs, the windes to blow, the ≈øpring to flow, the corn to grow, P≈ø. 147.18. the fruites to ≈øhew, the gardens and orchardes to fructifie, the woods to ra≈øtle with leaues, the meadowes to ≈øhine with varietie of gra≈ø≈øe and flowers, And Chry≈øo≈øtowe very excellently handling the ≈øame point with Cyprian, further ≈øhewes, that God hath in a ≈øorte made the night more beautifull then the day, by infinite varietie of bright and glittering ≈øtarres, and that hee hath beene more mindfull and mercifull then man would haue bin of him≈øelfe, who through the greedine≈ø≈øe of the World, would haue ouertoyled him≈øelfe; but that God made the night of purpo≈øe for his repo≈øe and re≈øt. In a word, hee ≈øayes (and that truly) euen of the≈øe earthly benefites and commodities, that although we were neuer ≈øo vertuous; nay, if wee ≈øhould dye a thou≈øand deathes, wee ≈øhould not be worthie of them. And the very heathen Poet con≈øidering this, could not choo≈øe but breake out into an admiration, ≈øaying: O how many things hath God created for mans delight, & heaped ioyes vpon him with a bountifull hand? Nay the Prophet Dauid con≈øidering this, could not chu≈øe but breake out into this wonderful admiration; P≈øal. 144.3. Lord what is man that thou take≈øt knowledge of him, or the ≈øon of man that thou make≈øt accouÃÑt of him. And al this hath God done (≈øayth Cyprian) to good and bad, to the harmle≈ø≈øe and the harmefull, Eccle≈ø. 9.2. to the religious and irreligious, to the holy and prophane, to the ≈øwearer, and to him that feareth an oath. And hee maketh (as our Sauiour Chri≈øt ≈øayeth in the Go≈øpel of Saint Mathew) Mat. 5.4.5. His ≈øunne to ≈øhine on the euill, and on the good, and ≈øendeth raine on the iu≈øt and vniu≈øt, Whence wee may well rea≈øon thus, that if GOD
dealeth ≈øo graciou≈øly with vs on earth, hee will do much more for vs, and to vs in heauen; if he be≈øtowed ≈øuch benefites vpon ≈øtrangers, nay vpon enemies; he hath better things in ≈øtore for his owne hou≈øehould; yea for vs, which are his friends‚ñ™ If he dealeth ≈øo liberally and bountifully with ≈ølaues, hee will be much more liberall and bountifull to vs which are his ≈øonnes in heauen. Againe, the excellencie of the creatures of God argues a greater; yea, incomparably greater excellency in the Creator him≈øelfe, as well doeth Barnard ob≈øerue. Thou wondre≈øt (≈øayeth hee) at the brightne≈ø≈øe of the Sunne, beautie in the flowers, ≈øauorie reli≈øh in bread, fertility in the earth, Now con≈øider that all are the gifts of God, and there is no doubt but that hee hath re≈øerued much more to him≈øelfe for thee in heauen, then he hath communicated and imparted to the Creatures here vpon earth. Againe, we may conceyue of the≈øe ioyes of heauen, Luk 12.27.28 by taking a view of the inferiour beauties. Con≈øider (≈øayth our Sauiour Chri≈øt) the Lillyes of the field; how they grow and flouri≈øh, I ≈øay vnto you that Salomon in all his glory was not like to one of the≈øe. All Salomons glorie not like to one Lillie? Hath God put ≈øuch glorie and gladne≈ø≈øe vpon the gra≈ø≈øe of the field? hath he ≈øo gorgeou≈øly attired them, which to day haue a being, and to morrow are cut downe, and ca≈øt into the furnace? How much more then ≈øhall be the glory and ioy of you in heauen, O yee of little faith? Therefore when wee meete with any thing that is excellent in the Cteatures, we may ≈øay to our ≈øelues, how much more excellent is hee that gaue them this excel ‚Ä¢ ency. When we finde admirable wi≈øedome in men, how they rule al creatures, by cunning ouercome them that are farre ≈øtronger then them≈øelues, ouertake them that are farre ≈øwifter then them≈øelues, outrunne the Sunne and Moone in di≈øcour≈øe, telling many yeares before hand what cour≈øes they mu≈øt hold, & when they ≈øhall be eclip≈øed, Let vs ≈øay to our ≈øelues how wi≈øe is that God, which gaue ≈øuch wi≈øedome vnto men?

Againe, when we ≈øee any thing ≈øtrong, as the Lyon, or the Elephant, Act. 40.15.16 Iob. 41.1. 1 King. 19.11. who≈øe ≈øtrength is de≈øcribed in the booke of Iob, or the whale, who≈øe ≈øtrength is al≈øo there de≈øcribed; or the winde which is ≈øayd in the fir≈øt booke of the Kings to bee ≈øo great and ≈øtrong, that it rent the mountaines & brake in peeces the rockes; or the thunder or ≈øuch like, at the huge noy≈øe whereof (as it is ≈øayde in the booke of Exodus) it made all the people in the Campe to feare and tremble; Ex. 19 16. Let vs then ≈øay, how ≈øtrong is that God, that giueth this ≈øtrength vnto them? Againe, when wee ≈øee rare beauty in men or women, or mo≈øt glorious colours in flowers, birdes and other creatures; Let vs then ≈øay, how farre more beautifull and amiable is that God, that giueth this beauty and comeline≈ø≈øe vnto them? And when wee ta≈øte things that are exceeding comfortable and ≈øweet, as honey, and ≈øuch like; Let vs then ≈øay; how ≈øweete and comfortable is that GOD that giueth that ≈øweetene≈ø≈øe?

Now from al this let vs conclude, that if the creatures can affoord ≈øuch plea≈øure, comfort, contentment, and delight; what will the Creator him≈øelfe doe? when we ≈øhall immediately enioy his glorious pre≈øence after death? In thy pre≈øence (≈øayth the P≈øalmi≈øt) P≈øal 16.11. is fulne≈ø≈øe of ioy, and at thy right hand there are plea≈øures for euermore.

Surely this world compared to the world to come, is as it were but a little village to the greate≈øt and mo≈øt ≈øpatious City: nay, it is but as it were a gatehou≈øe, or Porters lodge to the mo≈øt wide, glorious and magnificent Pallace of the greate≈øt Prince in the World; and if the Gatehou≈øe bee ≈øo fayre, how fayre and glorious is the Pallace it ≈øelfe?

Moreouer, con≈øider what great ods there is between Gods mediate and immediate pre≈øence to enioy him in the creatures, and to enioy him in him≈øelfe. The creatures, yea the mo≈øt excellent creatures, are as it were but a vayle or curtaine drawne between God and vs, which vayle or
curtaine being drawne a≈øide, wee ≈øhall ≈øee God face to face; and then how glorious will that ≈øight bee? And though we know not what it is to behold the face of God; yet herein con≈øi≈øteth the highe≈øt degree of our happine≈ø≈øe. I≈øa. 33.17. Therefore are the ioyes of the Saints in heauen ≈øuper ≈øuperlatiue, becau≈øe theyr eyes doe alwayes behold their King in the excellency of his beauty and glory. It is a plea≈øing ≈øight and delight≈øome to the eye to behold the Sunne, but that is (≈øayth Bernard) the true and only ioy indeed, which is conceyued from the Creator, not from the creature. Iohn the Baptist leaped in his mothers wombe, Luk. 1.41. when but the mother of his Maker came neere vnto him. The Wi≈øe men reioyced exceedingly when they ≈øaw but his Starre. The Beth≈øhemites reioiced greatly at the ≈øight of the Ark. Math 2.10: Were the≈øe cau≈øes of great and vnwonted ioy and gladne≈ø≈øe? 1 Sam. 6.13 theÃÑ much more are the Saints of God raui≈øhed with ioy in heauen, where they ≈øhal continually ≈øee and behold God face to face.

Wee are to con≈øider, that there is a twofold vi≈øion or ≈øight of God; the one, called by ≈øome of the learned vi≈øio viae, the ≈øight of the way, and means that bringeth home to God; the other vi≈øio patriae, the ≈øight of t ‚Ä¢ e Countrey, where God is, that is his home and habitation with his Saints and Angels.

They are happy that ≈øee the way, that bringeth and leadeth home to God, but more happy, that are at home in heauen dwelling, neuer to bee remoued out of his pre≈øence and Country. Of the≈øe two ≈øortes of vi≈øions meaneth the Apo≈øtle Saint Paul: When hee ≈øayth; 1 Cor 13.12 for now wee ≈øee through a gla≈ø≈øe darkely, but then wee ≈øhall ≈øee face to face.

Touching the fir≈øt kind of the ≈øight of God, which is termed vi≈øio viae, or (as Saint Paul) in a gla≈ø≈øe darkly, in a word this ≈øight con≈øi≈øteth in true faith and knowledge of God. And thus to ≈øee God by ≈øound and ≈øauing knowledge grounded vpon his word, and by a true and liuely
iu≈øtifying faith from this knowledge ari≈øing: This I ≈øay, is onely proper to Gods elect children, who in time ≈øhall come to ≈øee him at home face to face in the fulnes of ioies for euer. And touching vi≈øio patriae, a ≈øeeing of God in his Country, or his home, or heauenly habitation. Augu≈øtine writing vpon Gene≈øis ≈øayth, That the ble≈ø≈øed ≈øhall haue a three-fold ≈øight of God in heauen. To wit, they ≈øhall fir≈øt haue a ≈øpirituall, or they ≈øhall ≈øee the ble≈ø≈øed ≈øpirits & Angels; next, a body or corporall ≈øight of the ble≈ø≈øed redeemer.
