Now if the queene of Sheba could ≈øay ≈øo much, that the one halfe was not told her, and that his wi≈øedome and pro≈øperity exceeded the fame which ≈øhee before had heard of him, then much more may the child of God truly ≈øay, when he commeth in his owne per≈øon to behold a farre greater then Salomon, nay, Mat. 12.42. not ≈øo much as one quarter of the glory and ioyes of heauen was told him, and that the glory and ioyes thereof farre exceed the report, fame, and de≈øcription which he hath heard. For all the ioyes which we haue heard, or can heare of, when they are put all together, they are all but as one poore drop of water to the maine Ocean ≈øea, in compari≈øon of the ioyes which the Saints of God ≈øhall behold and enioy in their owne per≈øons in the kingdome of glorie. For no man knoweth them, but ≈øuch as enioy them, according to that which is ≈øaid in the booke of the Reuelation: To him that ouercommeth, Reu. 2.17. I will giue to eate of the hidden Manna, and will giue him a white ≈øtone, and in the ≈øtone a new name written, which no man knoweth ≈øauing bee that receiueth it.

Let me but ≈øhew you now what S. Augu≈øtine ≈øpeaketh of the ioyes of heauen: Wee may ≈øooner tell you (≈øaith hee) what they are not, then what they are. And hence it is that the euangelical Prophet E≈øay ≈øaith, I≈øay 64.6. That ≈øince the beginning of the world men haue not heard, nor perceiued by the eare, neither hath the eye ≈øeene (O God) be≈øides thee, what he hath prepared for him that waiteth for him. For there we ≈øhall ≈øee light that pa≈ø≈øeth all lights, which no eye hath ≈øeene; there wee ≈øhall heare a glorious ≈øound or harmonie, which pa≈ø≈øeth all harmonies, which no eare hath heard; there wee ≈øhall ≈ømell a mo≈øt ≈øweet ≈øent and ≈øauour, that pa≈ø≈øeth all ≈øweet ≈øents and ≈øauours, which no ≈øen≈øe hath ≈ømelt; there wee ≈øhall ta≈øte a mo≈øt plea≈øant and delightfull ta≈øte, that pa≈ø≈øeth all plea≈øant ta≈øtes, which no tongue hath ta≈øted; and there we ≈øhall finde ≈øuch plea≈øure and contentment, as pa≈ø≈øeth all contentments and plea≈øures, which no body euer had. Nay I can not hold my heart for my ioy, yea I cannot hold in my ioy for my heart, to thinke vpon this ioy and glorie, and to think that I that am now a ≈øilly poore worme vpon earth, ≈øhall hereafter be a glorious Saint in the kingdome of glorie, where is not onely true happine≈ø≈øe, but perfection of happine≈ø≈øe, not ≈øound ioy onely, but fulne≈ø≈øe of ioy, which are ≈øo ab≈øolute and ≈øtrange, that neither eye hath ≈øeene, to wit, eye mortall; nor eare hath heard, 1. Cor. 2.9. that is, eare of man hath not heard the like, neither can they enter into our heart, (though all our hearts were as large euery one, 1. King. 4.29. as the heart of Salomon, which God gaue vnto him, euen as large as the ≈øand that is on the ≈øea-≈øhore) to conceiue and vnder≈øtand them, if they were told vs, which are reuealed by the ≈øpirit, and but li≈øped out by S. Iohn in tho≈øe earthly ≈øimilitudes of gates, of pearles, of walles of ia≈øper, Reu 21.18.19.21,22. and of a ≈øtreet who≈øe pauement is gold, as we heard before.

Dan 12.3. But it may be here obiected, But in heauen (≈øaith the Prophet Daniel) they that be wi≈øe ≈øhall ≈øhine as the brightne≈ø≈øe of the firmament, and they that turne many vnto righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, ≈øhall be as the ≈øtarres for euer and euer. Now the firmament
hath not ≈øo much light as the ≈øtarres, which lighten it, and the ≈øtarres haue le≈ø≈øe light then the Sun that lightneth them, from whence therefore it ≈øeemeth that in heauen al≈øo there ≈øhould rather be ≈øome want, then ≈øuch fulne≈ø≈øe of heauenly ioyes and glorie? I an≈øwer, though in this condition of our heauenly life there may be degrees of glory, (In my fathers hou≈øe, ≈øaith our Sauiour Chri≈øt, Iohn 14.2. are many man≈øions,) yet there ≈øhall be no want of glory: ≈øome may be like the skie, ≈øome the ≈øtarres of the skie, yet all ≈øhall ≈øhine: ≈øome ve≈ø≈øels may hold more, ≈øome le≈ø≈øe, and yet all bee full: ≈øo one may haue more ioy then another, & there are ≈øundry mea≈øures of more or le≈ø≈øe glory in heauen. There is one glory of the Sunne, (≈øaith the Apo≈øtle) 1. Cor. 15 41: another of the Moone, and another glory of the ≈øtarres, for one ≈øtarre differeth from another in glory: but no mea≈øure ≈øhal lacke his fulne≈ø≈øe of life and glory there, where ≈øhall be a mea≈øure of ioy heaped vp, ≈øhaken together, pre≈ø≈øed downe and running ouer. And (as Bernard very excellently ≈øpeaketh) Luke 6.38. a mea≈øure without mea≈øure, where we ≈øhall be filled with ioy; yet being filled, wee ≈øhall ≈øtill de≈øire, le≈øt our fulne≈ø≈øe procure a loathing, and in de≈øiring we ≈øhall alwaies be filled, le≈øt our de≈øire beget a grieuing; neither can God giue more, nor man receiue more then we ≈øhall there enioy; for there we ≈øhall be repleni≈øhed and ≈øatisfied with ≈øuch a fulne≈ø≈øe of life, glory, and happine≈ø≈øe, ≈øo as wee ≈øhall not bee able to de≈øire, or to haue any more; euen as ve≈ø≈øels ca≈øt into the water, being ≈øo filled with water, that they can de≈øire or hold no more; and he that hath lea≈øt, ≈øhall haue enough. The rea≈øons hereof are the≈øe: Hell is contrarie to heauen; In hell there is a fulne≈ø≈øe of torment, in heauen therefore there mu≈øt be a fulne≈ø≈øe and perfection of glory and happine≈ø≈øe. Secondly, earthly kingdomes, and the kings therof haue as great an ab≈øolutene≈ø≈øe, as earth can affoord and giue them, and ≈øhal we thinke that heauen which can giue an entire, wil giue an impefect crowne of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe and glorie? Wil the kings of the earth dwel in ba≈øe cottages, and not in royal Courts and Pallaces? and ≈øhall the≈øe kings of a far
better kingdome want ioy and glorie, wheras mortall kings haue ≈øo great glorie and power? Princes on the earth dwell in royall palaces, ≈øometimes of Cedar and Iuorie, but they whom the Sonne of God hath made kings and prie≈øts vnto God his Father, Reu. 1.6. (as it is in the booke of the Reuelation) ≈øhall raigne in a glorious citie and pallace, who≈øe twelue gates are twelue pearles, Reu. 21.18. who≈øe wall is of Ia≈øper, and building of gold, and who≈øe ≈øtreetes ≈øhine as cleare gla≈ø≈øe. So ≈øaid he that ≈øaw all this glorie but darkely, or as Moy≈øes ≈øaw the land of Canaan in a very ≈øhort mappe or card afarre off, as it doth appeare in the booke of Deuteronomie.Deut. 34.1,2.3.4.

We ≈øee but the outward wall of this heauenly Court and City, and yet how glorious is it? and how deckt with ≈øtars as with ≈øparkling Diamonds? What would wee ≈øay, if wee could ≈øee into it, Mat. 17.1. and behold (though with Peter, Iames and Iohn at a glance or blu≈øh ≈øuperficially) the goodly pauement of heauen within, who≈øe floore is of gold, and wall about it garni≈øhed with precious ≈øtones? Mat. 4.8. And what is a kingdome here, where all the kingdomes of the world and the glorie of them were ≈øhewed in the twinkling of an eye, Luke 4 5. as it is in the Go≈øpel? if there were not hope of a better kingdome; where all ≈øhall be kings, and reigne with Chri≈øt eternallly. And they which here haue reigned as kings vpon the earth, ≈øhall lo≈øe nothing, but gaine immea≈øurably by the change: yea kings and queenes which haue beene nur≈øing fathers and nur≈øing mothers to the Church of God (as the Prophet ≈øpeaketh) when they come thither, I≈øay 49.23. ≈øhall ca≈øt away their Crownes as Elias, 2. King 2.13. when hee went vp by a whirlewind into heauen, let his cloake or mantle fall from him, and they ≈øhal repent nothing there, ≈øaue that they came no ≈øooner thither‚ñ™ and when they ≈øhall compare their earthly and heauenly kingdomes together, they ≈øhall ≈øay as S. Peter ≈øaid of the mount, Mat. 17.4. bonum e≈øt e≈ø≈øe hic, It is good to be here in heauen, but for the earth, they ≈øhall bee as loth to looke backe vnto it, as Moy≈øes to goe backe into the land of Egypt. For their pallaces ≈øhall then ≈øeeme pri≈øons, their golden chaines
golden fetters, their crownes cro≈ø≈øes, and all their earthly honors but burdens, and vexations. But when they ≈øhall looke vpon the face of God, they ≈øhall ≈øay to him with triumph as it is in the P≈øalme, With thee is the well of life, P≈øal. 16.11. in thy pre≈øence is the fulne≈ø≈øe of ioy, and at thy right hand are plea≈øures for euermore.

Thirdly, if Adams paradi≈øe and garden was ≈øo delight≈øome and plea≈øant, how plea≈øant and glorious is Gods owne ≈øeat of his owne re≈øidence? He ≈øpake it with a wondring tongue, who≈øe heart could not comprehend ≈øo infinite an excellencie, in ≈øaying (as we haue heard before) How glorious things are ≈øpoken of thee O thou city of God! P≈øal. 87.3. For though in the letter, this worthy Prophet ≈øpake of that earthly heauen, which he confe≈ø≈øed to be in the material tabernacle, becau≈øe of Gods pre≈øence, and the godly exerci≈øes of Gods people performed there, yet his meaning was vnder the cloud of the phra≈øe to direct Gods children to a higher tabernacle and hou≈øe of greater glory then that which was earthly, and vnder the doome of time.

Againe ≈øaith the ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle, 2. Cor. 3,7,8,9,10,11. If the mini≈øtration of death written and ingrauen in the ≈øtones was glorious, ≈øo that the children of I≈ørael could not ≈øtedfa≈øtly behold the face of Mo≈øes for the glory of his countenance, which glory was to bee done away, how ≈øhall not the mini≈øtration of the ≈øpirit bee rather glorious? For if the mini≈øtration of condemnation be glorious, much more doth the mini≈øtration of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe exceed in glorie. For euen that which was made glorious, had no glory in this re≈øpect, by rea≈øon of the glorie that excelleth. For if that which was done away was glorious, much more that which remaineth is glorious. And if the preaching of the Go≈øpel whereby God giueth his quickening ≈øpirit, working the life of grace in his elect, be glorious then much more ≈øhall the true profe≈ø≈øors of the Go≈øpel be made partakers of farre greater glorie in the kingdome of heauen.

Againe, wee doe reade in the fir≈øt booke of Samuel, 1. Sam. 18.23. that when Dauid was per≈øwaded by Saul, by the meanes of his
≈øeruant to become the Kings ≈øonne in law, it is there ≈øaid by Dauid, Seemeth it to you a light thing to be the Kings ≈øonne in law, ≈øeeing that I am a poore man, and lightly e≈øteemed? Then if it be accounted a great honor and glory to be a ≈øonne and childe to an earthly King, much more honorable and glorious it is to be the ≈øonne and childe of the King of heauen. Behold (≈øaith Saint Iohn) what manner of loue the Father hath be≈øtowed vpon vs, 1. Iohn 3.1. that wee ≈øhould bee called the ≈øonnes of God? Which glorie all the tongues of men and Angels (as wee haue heard before) can in no wi≈øe expre≈ø≈øe, as witne≈ø≈øeth the ble≈ø≈øed and glorious Apo≈øtle Saint Paul him≈øelfe, who was in it, 2. Cor. 12.1,2,3,4,5. and ≈øaw it; and therefore he ≈øaith, I knew a man in Chri≈øt aboue foureteene yeeres agoe, whether in the body, I cannot tell, or whether out of the bodie, I cannot tell, God knoweth; ≈øuch a one caught vp into the third heauen, and heard vn≈øpeakable words, which it is not lawfull or po≈ø≈øible for a man to vtter. So great and infinite are the glory and ioyes of the kingdome of God, as they cannot enter into vs: and therefore it is appointed, that we mu≈øt enter into them. Therefore it is ≈øaid, Matth. 25.21. Well done thou good and faithfull ≈øeruant, thou ha≈øt beene faithfull ouer a few things, I will make thee ruler ouer many things; enter thou into the ioy of thy Lord.

Now if the Queene of Sheba (as we heard before) pronounced the ≈øeruants of King Salomon happie, 1. King. 10.8. for that they ≈øtood continually before him, and heard his wi≈ødome, then much more happy are the Saints and ≈øeruants of God, who doe continually with his holy Angels, ≈øtand and behold the glorious pre≈øence of one which is greater then King Salomon, Matth. 18.10. euen the God of glory him≈øelfe. In which re≈øpect Saint Ambro≈øe on his death bed ≈øaid, We are happie in this, that we ≈øerue ≈øo good a Ma≈øter, Yea happie is the people (≈øaith the P≈øalmi≈øt) that is in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, P≈øal. 144.15. yea happie is that people, who≈øe God is the Lord. Yea ble≈ø≈øed and happie are all tho≈øe, which ≈øo liue in this world, that departing hence they may be a≈ø≈øured to come into ≈øo glorious a place and pre≈øence. Wee ≈øee by experience; when a Country-man hath beene trained vp
≈øometime in the Court, he forgetteth his clowni≈øh kinde of life, and becommeth a Courtier: let vs therefore leaue the ≈øpeeches, habite, fa≈øhion and manners of this wicked world wherein we liue, and inure our ≈øelues with the cu≈øtomes and cour≈øe of the Court of heauen: let all our thoughts, words and communication te≈øtifie, that (in ≈øpirit) wee are alreadie there: Let my minde (≈øaith Augu≈øtine) mu≈øe of it, let my tongue talke of it, let my heart loue it, and my whole ≈øoule neuer cea≈øe to hunger and thir≈øt after it.

In the meane time, till thou come into this glorious place and pre≈øence, aske of God by heartie and faithfull prayer, to giue thee grace entirely and from the bottome of thy heart, both to vnder≈øtand and de≈øire the ioyes and glory thereof, and ≈øo to be affected and raui≈øhed with the delight thereof, that euer and euery where thou maye≈øt be ≈øtirred vp to ≈øerue ≈øo good a Ma≈øter in purene≈ø≈øe and newne≈ø≈øe of life, that thou maye≈øt be made partaker thereof; P≈øal. 37.24. and pray with the Prophet that the Lord would guide thee with his coun≈øell, and afterwards receiue thee into his glory. Iohn 16.24. Aske and yee ≈øhall receiue (≈øaith our Sauiour) that your ioy may be full. And al≈øo labour and endeauour to bring as many as thou can≈øt to this glory, Dan. 12.3. For they that be wi≈øe (≈øaith the Prophet Daniel) ≈øhall ≈øhine as the brightne≈ø≈øe of the firmament, and they that turne many to righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, as the ≈øtarres for euer and euer.

Lift vp your heads O yee heauenly gates, and be yee lift vp yee euerlasting doores, that the King of glory may bring vs in. P≈øal. 24 7. I might much further amplifie and inlarge this matter; but the worke growing bigger then I thought it would, I forbeare; but as Painters, when they haue many millions and armies of men to ≈øet downe in a ≈ømall mappe, v≈øe onely to draw out ≈øome number of heads of men and ≈øet them together, leauing the whole number of heads and all the other parts and lineaments to the meditation of the beholders; euen ≈øo am I con≈øtrained through aboundance of matter, to propound only ≈øome general heads, and to leaue the amplification of them to your priuate meditations: and I hope
wi≈øe man will not refu≈øe precious Iewels, though they bee brought in a plaine and homely receptacle.

Iude 1.24,25. Now vnto him (≈øaith the holy Apo≈øtle Saint Iude) that is able to keepe you from falling, and to pre≈øerue you faultle≈ø≈øe before the pre≈øence of his glorie with exceeding ioy; to the onely wi≈øe God our Sauiour, bee Glory and Maie≈øtie, Dominion and Power, now and for euer, Amen.

P≈øal. 72.18,19. Ble≈ø≈øed bee the Lord God, the God of I≈ørael, who only doth wondrous things. And ble≈ø≈øed be his glorious name for euer, and let the whole earth be filled with his glorie, Amen, Amen.

To the which mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed place of glory, the Lord bring euery one of our ≈øoules, at the day of our death and di≈ø≈øolution, and that for Ie≈øus Chri≈øt his ≈øake, to whom with God the Father, and God the ble≈ø≈øed Spirit, three glorious Per≈øons, but one immortall God, be a≈øcribed all honor and glorie, both in heauen and earth, this day and euer. Amen.
